joy-of-jesus-smileymom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/194174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely the most addicting dip ever! I was skeptical that the ingredients would taste well together, and nothing more should be added (like bacon). Well, I used fresh parmesan, and it was perfect, better than cheddar. I tried adding bacon and it detracted from the taste. The dip was not mild, but not tearfully spicy either, so if you need it REALLY hot, doubling the jalepenos would suit you. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND using panko (Kikkoman makes a grocery-store version) crumbs on top of the parmesan (10/08 UPDATE TIP!!! MIX the 1/2 cup panko crumbs WITH your FRESH grated parmesan and sprinkle the mixture atop. It comes out SO crispy and golden, and prevents the cheese melting into a hard crust you can't scoop through. Perfect, perfect!); and you'll bake up a beautiful golden, crunchy coating -- that "deep-fried" taste! Do bake in the oven. Last but not least, the large crowds that have devoured this agree that the best DIPPER is TOASTED FRENCH BREAD slices (place on pan under the broiler for a couple *careful* minutes per side), distantly followed by butter crackers. Tortilla chips are the least favorite, and sourdough bread (my usual favorite) seemed too sharp to accentuate the dip. Hope that helps any questions YOU might have! =)

text:
Thank you for all of the wonderful comments!  I also use a whole 4 oz can of jalapenos, because I like it spicy.  I use REAL shredded parmesan on the top.  It does make the best "popper" flavor.  You just have to trust me.  In order to get the correct consistency, you have to stick to the recipe.  Do not substitute with sour cream and you must use the mayo.  The best presentation you can do is REAL shredded parmesan cheese on top, and bake it in the oven in a glass pie dish.  It comes out golden brown and gorgeous!  Mmmm...  Also, you'd think bacon would be great in this.  It's not.  Again, you just have to trust me.  People rate this recipe less than 5 stars when they add to it and that's not the recipe that I've shared.  Please stick to the recipe for the best results, and use the baked variation with real shredded parmesan cheese (not the green can stuff).  Enjoy!!!

text:
I took this to a football party & it was DEVOURED! i did what others suggested:  used 6 fresh jalapenos, used 1/2 C mayo & 1/2 C sour cream, omitted the chiles, added 1/2 C shredded cheddar, & finished it off with italian bread crumbs & a sprinkle of cheddar.  I served it with sliced baguette.  next time I make it, I'm going to try adding some pepperjack cheese.  It could have been a bit spicier for me.

text:
W-O-W!  This is SO yummy.  I took the advice of others and used more diced jalapenos - - I drained a 7.75 oz. can and used that.  The dip had heat, but no one said it was too hot for their taste buds.  I also used shredded Cheddar cheese (1/2 in the cream cheese mixture and 1/2 sprinkled on top.) because that is more an ingredient in poppers than Parmesan.  And because others suggested it, I also sprinkled lightly with bread crumbs for that "fried" popper taste.  Baked at 400 degrees for 20 minutes and served it with Tostito Scoops. This "dip" tasted exactly like jalapeno poppers.   Try this, you will not be disappointed.

text:
WOW!  This was fantastic.  I halved the recipe and used equal parts green chilis and jalaps.  I did not use parm, because that didn't seem very "poppery" to me.  Instead, I mixed in some odds and ends of 2% shredded cheeses I had:  sharp cheddar, co-jack, and a mexican mix. I also used 1/2 C light mayo and 1/2 C sour cream because I prefer sour cream to mayo (and per earlier suggestions).  I baked in the oven and served w/fresh french bread.  I covered the top w/bread crumbs (and sprayed w/PAM to "crisp") prior to baking.  Yum, yum!

text:
I made this for a party and no one really cared for it. Most of it didn't get eaten. The mayonnaise was overpowering for us. I decided to try again with some modifications. I used fresh jalapeno's. I added some cumin to the cream cheese. I used sour cream and no mayo, mixed in some cheddar cheese, and thinking of some poppers a local restaurant, I added a small can of crab meat, and added breadcrumbs to the top.  I served it again to our friends and with the modifications it was a huge hit.

This recipe ROCKS!!!   I baked it in the oven following the directions to the "T".  Took it out of the oven and placed in a crock pot to maintain the gooey warmness and it worked like a charm!   I cannot tell you how many raves reviews this recipe gets...It is unbelievable!! Crock pot is a must to keep it warm and gooey!  Tortilla Chips are a must!  ****Additional note. If you double this recipe I had to cut the mayo down to 1.5 cups to capture the same flavor as the original single recipe.

text:
I have tried MANY different jalapeno popper and jalapeno-popper-esque recipes...none of them impressed me and all of them took SO MUCH WORK.  This recipe is completely the opposite!!  HOLY COW is it amazing!  The past reviewers and recipe submitter are absolutely correct - it DOES taste exactly like a popper and it is SOOOO easy to make!  Every single person who tried this at our 4th of July BBQ fell in love with it - they just couldn't stay away! Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU for this recipe!!  I will definitely bring this to many future gatherings!  I topped with Panko bread crumbs (sprayed with cooking spray) and baked for 30 minutes at 375 degrees.  UPDATE:  I've been using two cans of green chilies and a full can of jalapenos.  Sounds like a lot, but it's perfect in my opinion!  It's dangerously addicting though.  My boyfriend's brother likes to make tortilla pinwheels with the mixture - it's pretty tasty this way, but I prefer Ritz crackers.

text:
Forget the chopped green chiles and canned jalapenos.   I omitted those, and ran about 8 fresh jalapenos through a blender and added that instead.  A much fresher flavor, and the dairy mutes the hotness of the fresh peppers quite a bit.

text:
Very good!  I made this for a pool party last night, and everyone loved it.  Even the picky kids liked it!  I couldn't find fresh jalapenos, so I used "tame" jalapenos from a jar.  Because the jarred jalapenos had less heat, I used double the amount.  It had just enough kick without being too spicy for the pickiest guests.  I followed another reviewer's suggestion and added 1/2 cup of panko bread crumbs to the parmesan topping.  It turned out great!  I highly recommend serving this with toasted baguette slices.  I sliced the baguette about 1/4 inch thick and placed the slices on a cookie sheet.  I popped them in a 350 degree oven for about 5 minutes.  Like other reviewers, I recommend baking this in a pie dish.  I plan to make it again with fresh jalapenos for a little more heat!

This was really wonderful.  I made is as written, but accidentally added half of the Parmesan to the dip.  The other half went on top with about 1/3 cup Panko bread crumbs. Good, don't get me wrong, and we don't love very spicy food, but more jalapeno would make this pop!

text:
This dip is amazing!!!! I took it to a Ohio State football party and it's a request from my friends for every party ever since! I recommend using 1/2 cup sour cream and 1/2 cup mayo. The sour cream makes it special. I also use the whole can of jalapenos (drain about 70% of the juice out first, or leave the juice if you want it extra spicy!) I recommend also mixing in about 1/2 cup bread crumbs then sprinkling bread crumbs on top along with grated parmesean. Bake in the oven then serve on toasted french bread slices! Mmmm...

text:
A pretty good dip for a crowd!  I took previous reviewers' advice and opted for safe (mild) by using fresh serano peppers (4) and jalapeno peppers (3), membranes and seeds removed.  Added some salt as well because the canned stuff contains salt.   Pretty much everyone liked the dip even though it was barely spicey.  The topping mixture of 1/2 cup Panko and 1 cup grated parmesan gave it a pleasing crunch texture which people liked.  Next time I'll try leaving the pepper membranes intact to see how hot it gets.

I tried this because my family LOVES stuffed jalapenos.  I wanted something that was easier but real close to those.  This one is the next best thing. It will go into my keep file.  I read the reviews and also used panko on the top. I also used freshly grated parmesan, and I baked it instead of using the micro.   I also doubled the diced jalapenos as my guys really like the hot stuff.  I can't eat it when I make it this hot, but when I use the orginal recipe, it's just right for me. I made this for our camping trip over Thanksgiving, and among the 10 other appetizers put out, this is the one that went first, and was gone in less than 10 minutes.  I'm making this for a New Year's Eve party, and will make both kinds. I'm also going to try adding some bacon bits (real ones) and I think that will only add to how great this is.  I'll update later and let you know how it went over. I highly recommend this recipe.  You can't go wrong with it. Thanks Denise :)

text:
Excellent!!!   Here's the changes I made: -2 (8 ounce) packages cream cheese, softened -1 cup Hellman‚Äôs mayonnaise -2 ‚Äì 4 ounces canned diced jalapeno peppers, drained really well -3/4 cup shredded Monterey jack cheese -1 cup grated Parmesan cheese -1 cup Panko bread crumbs 1. Stir together cream cheese and mayonnaise in a large bowl until smooth, stir in jalapeno peppers and Monterey jack cheese. Pour mixture into an oven safe serving dish. Bake about 20 -30mins. at 375 degrees. Combine Parmesan cheese with Panko bread crumbs and sprinkle on top of spread. Bake again until the topping is browned and dip is bubbling hot.  Best served with lightly toasted French bread slices.  The amount of jalapenos you use depends on your taste.  I used 4 oz. of hot peppers. and it wasn‚Äôt too hot.  It also depends on if the peppers you use are mild, medium or hot.

AMAZING!!! I made this for my family thanksgiving potluck and it was GONE within half an hour. everyone asked me either to make it for them or the recipe it was a hit.
i did change the recipe up a little and i also thought it was great.
i used 3 packages of cream cheese, one package of sour cream. i roasted 8 jalapenos, removed the skin. deseeded 4 and blended it up. i creamed together the cream cheese and sour cream, added blended jalapenos and 8oz of pepper jack cheese (def do this) and topped it off ith bread crumbs and parmesan for 20 mins at 375. Definitely will be my staple go-to item for future potlucks and get togethers.

text:
We all LOVED this!!   I followed the recipe exactly, except for sprinkling a bit more Parmesean cheese on top and baking it for 15 minutes as mentioned in the footnote.  I think 2 oz of diced Jalapenos (2 tbs) is the right amount of heat for a crowd since not all will like it hot.  My husband, who does not like hot foods, loved this as well as my brother who loves hot and spicy foods.  It met all taste preferences.  I did put the jalapenos and chilies in a food chopper for a few seconds so no one would bite into a jalapeno unexpectedly.   I served this with Keebler Club Snack Sticks, Original flavor (like Club crackers).  Perfect!  I'm sure it would be great with toasted French baguettes too.  The only thing I may do differently next time is to heat the dip in the microwave as indicated and/or in a small Crock Pot to keep it warm.  When baked in the oven, the cheese on top made a slight crust that I found annoying when trying to dip through it once it started to cool. I think this is best served warm. Thanks for such a great recipe, Denise!!  Can't wait to make this again . . . and again.
UPDATE:  Just made this again but this time just put all the ingreditents in a small crockpot and heated on low.  The flavor is exactly the same and the crowd loved it!  Definitely a keeper!

country:
None
text:
This is just the best spread EVER!!  As others said, totally addicting flavor.  Made it for my son's Super Bowl party, and everyone raved about it!! In order to control the heat, I used 3 fresh jalapenos, seeds and membrane removed - placed the halves in boiling water for only a couple of minutes, just to soften a bit, then cut into small dice.  I also mixed 1/2 cup Kikkoman panko crumbs with 1 cup of shredded parmesan (the kind in the small plastic tubs) and sprinkled over the top, then baked at 350 degrees for about 20 minutes.  This is fantastic hot, but any leftovers (good luck on that!) is great cold with crackers or baguette slices, or anything else you may have on hand!  (NOTE:  preparing the jalapenos as above resulted in NO  HEAT - ONLY FLAVOR - great for those of us who cannot tolerate spicy foods!)

text:
This recipe is AMAZING!  I was looking for a crowd pleasing recipe for my end of the school year department party, and this was a huge hit!!!  I did make a few changes to the recipe though.  I doubled the jalapenos to 4oz and added about 2/3 cup parmesan cheese into the mixture.  Then on top I covered with a combination of 3/4 cup panko and 1 cup parmesan cheese.  Bake uncovered at 375 for 15 min, then broil just until browned and beautiful.  I served with homemade crustinis (just bake the bread slices brushed with melted mixture of butter, olive oil, salt, pepper, and garlic salt).  DELICIOUS!!

This is SO good.  I make it for potlucks at work and everyone always expects it and asks for the recipe.  I make it a little lower in fat sometimes by using half Greek yogurt, half mayo, and low fat cream cheese. It is delicious warm or cold.

text:
This is wonderful!!!  Instead of serving it as a dip, I cut a loaf of french bread longways and toasted it in the oven (350 degrees, just for a few minutes).  Once it was a little bit browned (not so much that the bread was hard, but just enough so the spread wouldn't make the bread soggy), I spread this along the length of both sides.  I put it back in the oven to warm up for about 10 minutes and pulled out again to cool to room temperature.  When it was cool enough that the topping wasn't too gooey, I sliced the loaf into slices and served.  Everyone raved and many asked for the recipe!  I will make this again very soon!  Thanks for sharing! :)

text:
Took this to a card party and had many requests for the recipe. I did take other reviewers advice and used two cans of jalapenos, 1/2 mayo & 1/2 sour cream, put half of the parmesan cheese in the mix and mixed the other half with panko breadcrumbs and sprinkled on top. I didn't microwave, but baked it at 350 for about 15 mins until the topping was browned and the dip was bubbly. Served with Fritos Scoops corn chips and Triscuit Thin Crisps, and everyone liked the Triscuits better. Will definitely make again!

text:
This was the hit of the party.  

Only use freshly grated parmesan - this will alter the taste if you don't.  When I used the Kraft stuff this dip was good...but not like a jalepno popper.  More like a parmesean cream cheese dip.

Changes: whole can of jalapenos and 3 fresh chili peppers (this was a spicy dip).  Sprinkled a little bit of bread crumbs on top w/ the parm.  

TASTED JUST LIKE A JALAPENO POPPER!!

Served with bite-sized Tostitos.

Awesome dip!!! Will definitely make again!  I made this for a work pot-luck and followed the recipe exactly (no substitutions).  The only modification I made was to heat it up in a crock pot. I cut the cream cheese blocks into smaller pieces and threw all the ingredients in the crock pot and heated up on low for about 2 hours, stirring occasionally to make sure everything melted and blended. Right before serving I topped with the Parmesan Cheese.  Served it with Pretzel Thins and Bagel Chips and it was gone by the time I went up for seconds. Had so many people ask for the recipe! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this receipe for Christmas Eve appetizer party and it was a HUGE hit! Everyone wanted the receipe.  I changed just a few little things...I used the fire roasted green chilies, used 2-3 fresh jalapenos instead of the canned, added some chopped garlic and a little bit of chipotle Chulola sauce (its like Tabasco).  I topped it with a mix of Panko breading and shredded Parmesan cheese to mimic the breading on a popper, and baked for 30 min.  I served it with tortilla chips.  I thought my family was going to lick the dish clean!!  My boyfriend enjoyed it so much he asked me to make it again for New Years.  **As a side note, I did add some bacon, just 2 strips chopped, but it really didn't add anything to the dip.  When my cousin asked what was in the dip he was suprised that there was bacon in it.

text:
Fantastic!  Just took this out of the oven a half hour ago and three of us have already devoured half of it.  Used the same ingredients but as others suggested I used l/2 mayo and l/2 sour cream and the whole 4 oz can of jalapenos.  That made it just right.  I also added l/2 cup shredded sharp cheddar cheese to the mix.  To the top cup of grated parmesan cheese, I added l/2 cup of plain panko bread crumbs.  We liked eating it with a sliced french baguette and tostitos but it woud be absolutely wonderful on anything.  It fit perfectly into a l0" round baking dish.  Baked at 350 for l/2 hr.  Thank you for this great creamy delicious spread!!  LOVE IT

text:
It's good as is but I like to add a thin layer of cheddar on the top and broil at the end... delicious and looks a bit more interesting.  I also use 4 large fresh jalapenos instead of canned and bake at 375 for 20 minutes.  Absolutely amazing.  Oh, I find it faster and easier to puree the mayo with the peppers, and then use a hand mixer to whip the mayo mixture with the cream cheese - really mixes it well and gives it a silky smooth texture.

I made this to take to an office Christmas party.  Of the 6 women there, 5 immediately asked me for the recipe - it was THAT good.  So simple to make that I'm making it again this weekend for our Sunday School Christmas party!   I did use "real" parmesan cheese grated (not the green stuff in the can) and mixed it with 1/2 C. This was terrific. Everyone raved about it at my son's birthday party. Even the people who didn't think they would like it. I did do two things slightly differently, I only had fat free cream cheese and light mayo so I added a 1/4 cup of cheddar cheese to increase the cheese flavor. I then topped with the parm. cheese but also a few breadcrumbs sprayed with Pam so that it browned up nicely. I think next time I would use full flavor ingredients (would have this time if I had them) and will skip the bread crumbs. I don't think they need them.

text:
Great quick yummy appetizer.  I used a 7oz can of sliced jalapenos/drained and it wasn't too spicy.  Sprinkled with both the parmesan cheese and some toasted bread crumbs I made with french bread. (Tear the bread and pulse in the blender until fine and then toast dry on the stovetop.)
I had to take to a party the next day so I microwaved everything but the topping in a plastic bowl the night before. When I arrived at the party, I reheated in same bowl, then poured into pretty bright red dish and microwaved 2 minutes with topping.  Add whole jalapeno for presentation

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To celebrate the start of the football season my work had a contest to see who could make the best dip. I won! Apparently the big grand prize is a trophy for a year and "bragging rights". My department Director has been talking trash all week about how he was going to win. After I won I loudly bragged about it until he told me to leave early.


I used four fresh jalapeno's and one fresh green chili. Took out all seeds and gave them a quick hit in the mini food processor.  Mixed them together with the mayo and cream cheese and put in the fridge overnight. Next day covered with a mixture of panko bread crumbs and fresh Parmesan cheese before baking about 30 minutes at 350. People at work kept opening the oven while it was baking so the oven was most likely around 250 - 300 while baking.


Served with pieces of thinly sliced Baguette bread.


First, but definitely not last, time I will make this.

Thank you!

text:
I wanted a new recipe for our Girls weekend. Since it was just for me to try, and so many cooks used different ingredients than what was written, I wanted to test it both ways. I made half of the recipe-1 cream cheese,1/2 cup Mayo and 3 large fresh jalapenos w/ seeds. Mixed that up real good, then I split it in half. For the "original" one I added  some green chilies, freshly shredded parmesan and some breadcrumbs on top. For the other half I added some fresh garlic, cheddar cheese and only breadcrumbs on top. Baked at 375 about 30 minutes. I LOVED the original version!!  The cheddar cheese version was just ok. I ate it with fresh french bread (warmed but not toasted--tasted great with the bread soft & warm) and Tostitos Cantina Tortilla Chips...they are wonderful(extra thin and crispy)!! The original version has made it to the Girls Weekend! Thanks for sharing Denise! Original Version RULES!! And yes...it tastes like a popper!

text:
I made a variation on this recipe that I absolutely loved.  I took this recipe and turned it into a mac and cheese.  

My grocery store didn't have canned diced jalapeno peppers, so I used 2 tbls of a jar of chopped and I diced them up myself.  I mixed it according to the directions but instead of putting it in the microwave I mixed it into a pan of macaroni noodles.  I put that mixture into a baking  pan and topped it with handfulls of shredded cheese and on top of that i liberally sprinkled with parmesan cheese.  Baked on 350 for about 15 minutes and it was absolutely amazing! 

Thanks for this lovely recipe, I never would have thought of it myself!

I'd give it 10 if I could.  I wasn't so sure about this one but followed as written (no sour cream, no onions, no bacon!) with the exception of using 5-6 fresh jalepenos chopped (because I had them)It gets devoured in a flash. I've tried a reader suggestion and added panko to the top - it was good too, but it doesn't need it.  I agree with the submitter, use fresh grated parmesan on top (yes, I thought it was weird too - it's not the same without it and green top jar stuff is a poor substitute)  
You have given us a new family fav.  Thanks so much!  (PS - having it tonight for dinner - oh my bulging thighs!)  SO worth it!

I guess I had very high expectations for this dip, based on all the reviews. It was good but not the best dip I've ever had. I did halve the recipe and I used the mayo/ sour cream combo along with some fresh jalapenos. Also added the bread crumbs to the cheese on top and baked it like everyone suggested.  Maybe it would be good as a filling for jalapenos (if you were to make your own). It just seemed to be missing something on its own. I will definitely try it again though.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I made this dip to take to a Super Bowl party.  Unfortunately, no one there had ever tasted a jalapeno popper before.  Some were reluctant to try it for fear of the spiciness/heat.  I used 3 fresh jalapenos instead of the canned, and followed other reviewers suggestions and used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream, then 1/2 of the grated parmesan mixed into the spread while the other 1/2 baked on top with some Panko crumbs blended with it.  Baked until brown on top at 350 for about 30 min. and served with toasted baguette slices.  While I thought the dip was pretty good, I was a bit disappointed.  According to the reviews, it was going to transcend me into another universe...that just didn't happen.  Sometimes reviewers go to the extreme with their reviews, sounding as if they have never eaten good food before!  It builds the  expectation for an out-of-this-world experience, which ultimately results in a bit of a let down.  It was good, but not heavenly.  UPDATE:This dip tasted much better the next day after the flavors had a chance to meld overnight.  I would probably make this again, only I would blend it a day or two ahead of time and bake it on the day I want to serve it.

text:
I have no words to describe how tasty this is! I am so happy this was posted. I LOVE jalapeno poppers but never make them because it's just time consuming. This has that yummy popper flavor and all its missing is the breading. I have served this on small toasted bread rounds, crackers, chips and my kids favorite... celery sticks. It's so easy to make and a great flavor. I make it like the recipe calls but we prefer to eat it after chilled over night. I also take some raspberry seedless jam and mix in a little cayenne pepper that I keep on the side, it adds a little fruity zip like some places have to dip the poppers in. Everyone loves this recipe!

Make sure parmesan cheese is room temperature before baking otherwise it just becomes all crusty and not melty.  In other words if you refrigerate it for later baking, add the cheese/panko mixture to the top just before baking.

GREAT AND EASY!!!  I tweaked the recipe a bit by using neufchatel instead of cream cheese and Olive Oil Mayonnaise, for a lower fat version.  I topped with the Panko (highly recommended), and Romano cheese instead of Parmesan since that is what I had on hand. It was a hit at my football party, everyone loved it and wants me to bring it next time!

text:
This is pretty  good.  Not over the top great but pretty good.  I have a party comming up next week and decided to give this a run by.  I never serve anything I haven't tried first.  People suggested canned Jalepenos and fresh Jalapenos so I split the recipie and tried both.  I also used a digital scale to measure ingrediants cause that is how I do things.

I preferred the canned Jalopenos because they were hotter but my wife preferred the fresh ones.  The real test was how did it taste the next day.  The fresh Jalapenos won but not by much but the real test was, can this be made a day ahead.  The answer is yes but bring it to room temp before you serve it.

Overall, It will be at the party but it is NOT knock your socks off.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times.  My family and friends love it.  I do not use the microwave.  after mixing together the creamed cheese, mayo, chilies and peppers, I put a handful of cheese (romano or parm) into the mixture, probably a good half cup.  then I spread the mixture into a pie pan.  Take another handful of cheese and stir it around in a bowl with a handful of panko bread crumbs.  Sprinkle this over the top and bake for about 30 minutes at 350 until golden on top.  It's great warm and also cold if you have any left over.

text:
What a great, easy, appetizer.  The only change I made was adding shredded cheddar cheese rather then parmasen cheese since most popper recipes called for it.  What was great is the ability to just add more jalapenos if you like it spicier. It was also good not warmed up, but at room temperature.  The jalapenos intensify with the warmth.  A make over for sure

country:
None
text:
I will never buy poppers again! This dip is UNBELIEVABLE! The first time I made this recipe, I did so exactly as specified. It was REALLY good, but I tweaked it the next time using other posters advice and and it was perfect! I used fresh jalapeno peppers (enough to make just over a cup once chopped) omitted the green chilis (only because my grocer didn't have them in stock), used 3/4 cup of mayo and 1/4 cup sour cream, added the parmesan cheese to the cream cheese/mayo mixture, used panko crumbs on top - I feel this is the key to making it taste JUST like poppers, and made the day before eating (I found it was that much tastier the next day as the flavors had chance to really meld together)....OH MY!! I also agree that this dip is DELICIOUS cold! Will make this again and again!

text:
Like so many have said - it really does taste like jalapeno poppers, only much easier to eat. Made it with only 1 block cream cheese, 4 oz green chilies, about 3 oz chopped jarred jalapenos, maybe 1/2 c light miracle whip; added about 1/2 c shredded cheddar in the mix. Topped w/ the canister parmesan (all I had), and panko crumbs sprayed w pam. Gone in a flash - we were divided over whether we preferred it on toasted baguette or tortilla chips - delicious on both! Thanks for an awesome recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AMAZING!!  I took this app to a ladies evening in my neighborhood.  Everyone loved it and asked for the recipe.  My changes: I couldn't find chopped jalapenos at my grocery so I bought a 7.75 oz. jar of jalapeno slices for nachos and chopped them up myself.  I used about 3/4 of the jar so I figure I used about 6 oz.  The dip was not too hot and quite honestly probably just right, though I might tempt fate next time and use the whole jar!  I creamed the mixture the night before and put in refrigerator overnight.  I took out 1 hour before baking. I used real shredded parm cheese which I tossed with 1/2 c panko bread crumbs.  I topped the filling with the bread crumb cheese mixture and then generously sprayed it with olive oil Pam to ensure a crispy topping.  I baked in 400 oven until internal temp registered 165.  Then I broiled for 2 minutes.  I baked and served this in a shallow Corningware dish.  I served with French bread toasts that I prepared myself - slicing the bread, brushing with olive oil and sprinkling with kosher salt before crisping in a 450 oven.  Oh!  SO AMAZING!

text:
OK...My tweak is that I roast fresh jalapenos on the grill, till golden not burnt,( you can broil them) seed and dice them. Forget mayonaise and go for light sour cream and light cream cheese. Mince a 2-4 teaspoons fresh onion, finely grate some cheese,(cheddar or Monteray Jack are my faves). A a couple of tablespoons of finely chopped cilantro. Mix it all together & chill...Now if you want to get exotic, mix in some chopped cooked shrimp and serve it in a papaya, canatlope. Serve it with cucumber strips or fruit wedges. the cool & hot compliment each other very well.

text:
I made this last Sunday for my Super Bowl "Party of One". So, I cut it in 1/2 using 1 pk. cream cheese, 1/4 c. mayo, and 1/4 c. sour cream. But when I added the peppers, I also thought it didn't have enough of a "kick", so I threw in an entire 4oz. can of both the chiles and jalapenos.  It does get hotter as it sets, but still not overpowering.  I mixed a bit of grated parm in with the dip, but then topped it with 1/2 c. grated parm and 1/2 c. of Panko bread crumbs.  This was my first time using Panko bread crumbs and they are wonderful--gave the dish a really nice appearance.  I baked it at 375 for 30 mins and then broiled it til the bread crumbs were lightly browned.  This was my "test run" and I am making this dip again for our church's Souper Bowl of Caring mission project wrap-up.  I'm sure it will be a big hit!  Thanks so much for this recipe!

Definately tasted like a Jalapeno Popper!  I used freshly grated parm - 1/2 in mix & 1/2 on top.  Topped w/combination of parm, panko and olive oil.  Only thing - the store was out of canned jalapeno so I had to use fresh.  I used 2 1/2 and scraped the seeds for fear it'd be too spicy.  Could've safely doubled it.  You could taste the jalapeno but there was no real kick.  Everyone loved it though :)  Great recipe.  Thanks!

text:
This was delicious. I made it for the first time and took it to our annual family Christmas party last night. NO LEFTOVERS. I did as others had recommended and combined 1 c. grated parm. cheese w/ 1 c. Panko bread crumbs. I baked it 30 mins., then put it under the broiler for approx. 3-5 mins (just until it was a light brown). It created a yummy, crunchy topping...just like an actual popper. Served w/ Wheat thins, but I'm sure it would have been great w/ Triscuits or toasted french bread. Packs a little punch too.

city:

country:
None
text:
WOW! My husband and I both LOVED this recipe! After reading all of the reviews, particularly the review by the original recipe submitter, I decided to make the spread according to the recipe the first time. It was absolutely delicious. Many of the changes made by other reviewers, such as adding other cheeses or additional seasoning, are sure to be delicious but just make this into a jalapeno cheese dip. If you want the authentic popper taste, follow this recipe. We did add 4 oz of jalapenos as the recipe submitter said in her review that she does. I am sensitive to spicy food and this was a little too hot for me, so next time I will make it with only 3 oz of jalapenos. Also, as the spread cooled, the layer of parmesan on top did kind of toughen up, so next time I will stir 1/2 or more of the parmesan into the spread and then sprinkle the rest on top. We ate the spread on sliced, toasted baguette and also tried it with Ritz crackers. I highly recommend the sliced baguette. This spread is sure to be a hit at social gatherings! I will make it again and again.

text:
We really enjoyed this dip.  It is very good (even though my brother called it "a heart attack waiting to happen." :-)  I served it with tortilla chips and the salty chips were great with the spicy spread.  I eyeballed the jalapenos and also chopped up a fresh jalapeno and put most into the dip, then left a few slices for garnish.  I might use a little more peppers next time.  I added about 1/2 cup of sharp chedder to the spread and then sprinkled some on top.  I'm glad I used some cheddar.  I also added a dash of garlic powder and may add more next time.  Although this dip was good, next time I may do 1/2 c. mayo, 1/2 c. sour cream instead of the 1 c. mayo.  Try this spread.  You won't be disappointed!

YUMMY!  Used low fat mayo, low fat cream cheese, freshly grated parm, 1 small can of green chile's and 2 of the jalapeno's including the juices for more flavor, a dash of onion powder and garlic powder.  Toasted panko bread crumbs with some parmesan cheese until golden brown.  Took it all to work in separate containers.  Then I microwaved the dip until bubbly hot.  Then I sprinkled panko bread crumbs on top.  Served with tortilla chips and toasted baguette.  Tasted very rich despite the low fat version!  Winner!!!

text:
I think it's fair to rate this, even though I made some minor changes. I followed the advice of a couple of other reviewers and used 6 (picked right from the garden!) jalape√±os, chopped and mostly seeded. I also melted about 2 TBS butter, which I mixed with about 1/2 cup panko crumbs and the fresh Parmesan, and then topped the cheese mixture with the buttery crumb mixture. I baked the dish at 375 F for about 20 minutes, or until golden brown and heated through. I only had Ritz crackers, but we could hardly stop ourselves from finishing the whole plate in one sitting! Thanks for an easy, marvelous recipe!

text:
New to this website and this my first review.  Recipe sounded very easy and also delicious. Finally made this tonight. I  followed the directions, only thing I did was add the whole can/4oz of Jalape√±os because I mean, we are mexican, we like spicy. Got everything mixed in, sprinkled top with cup of parmesan cheese and I left it in the fridge  about 45 min, I wanted the jalapeno flavor to mix really good. I then put in microwave for 3 min and my kids were in the kitchen while in the microwave because of the delicious smell. It was amazing, everybody loved it. The only thing I will do differently is add more jalape√±os because I want a lil bit more punch. Thanks!

country:

text:
Amazing!  Have had it requested at three different events this week.  I skip canned everything and remove seeds first then blanch jalapeno's fresh.  I added extra 1/4 C sharp cheddar, 1/4 tsp jalapeno seasoning and topped with panko and bake for that crispy touch.  For those hard core hot budded souls, I made a relish with the seeds and inner's from the jalapeno:  run jalapeno seeds and rinds through processor for a few seconds and add 1/4 cup each of water, rice vinegar, fish sauce and 1 TBSP sugar, 1 TBSP Lemon or Lime juice.  Just a dab on top of spread, Very hot but incredibly good!

text:
This is a simple yet delicious recipe. I followed as instructed with the exception of the Jalapenos, added more as I like things spicy. Also I didn't have the full amount of parmesan cheese needed and added sharp cheddar. Everyone at my Christmas dinner raved about this recipe. I think the key to this dish is to use real cheese. I served with both pita chips and tortilla chips. I think the consensus was that it was better with tortilla chips. Definitely a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This spread is incredibly good. Used Cubanelles and jalapenos from my garden, roasted. The roasting of the peppers gave them a nice smooth taste and texture yet still having heat. Love that good char taste from the grill. I swapped out the Parmesan Cheese with shredded Monterey  Jack. The Monterery was so so good but eliminating the Parm also eliminated the salt element that the spread needs so I garnished this with crumbled bacon. I baked off Phyllo Tart Shells, heated the spread, filled the tarts and garnished with bacon crumbles. WOW Thanks for sharing Denise.

text:
Delicious!  I used 6 fresh jalapenos from my garden, but I removed the seeds and membranes and I think next time I will either use the whole pepper or use more peppers because the dip was very mild.  I followed the recommendations of others and used 1/2 cup each of mayo and sour cream, and added some cheddar to both the dip and mixed it with the fresh parm on top.  I didn't have any breadcrumbs but we didn't mind the "cheese crust" that formed.  We tried it with cucumber slices and that was tasty, but our favorite was Italian bread, thin-sliced and toasted (the store was out of French bread).  Thanks for this great recipe!

I've made this dip SO many times and even after its gotten cold people still attack it :) I usually add a cup of shredded Chedder or pepperjack to the mix and reserve the parm to mix with the breadcrumbs on top. None
text:
Very good dip.  Made exactly as stated.  At first I used only 2 ounces of jalapeno.  That didn't have enough "kick" so I added the rest of the can, for a total of 4 ounces of jalapeno.  Tasted alot better, but still wasn't quite right.  I think when I make it again I will make sure the jalapeno peppers are chopped up real fine, instead of how they were chopped straight from the can.  If they were more finely chopped, the pepper flavor would be more consistent throughout the entire dip.  In my opinion it would be more like a "popper" that way.  I also will try baking the cheese, maybe with some bread crumbs as others have suggested...just to get the crispy popper experience!

Just made this! very good, didnt give 5 star because I made a few changes. I love spicy things, and this really was not spicy, so i added 2 4 oz cans of jalapenos and left out the green chilis. used half sour cream half mayo. did not use parmasean cheese instead mixed with shreded pep jax chz and colby jack chz. also added a bit of cayane pepper. topped it with more chz, a bit of bread crumbs  baked for 20 mins at 350. served with fresh bread that i broiled for 3 mins on each side! hope this helps was soooooooooooooo amazing

This is a wonderful recipe!  I only made slight changes to it.  I added Panko bread crumbs on top and the parmesian cheese and then baked it until it was hot.  I seemed a little runny when I took it out but the consistency was great as it cooled.  Also, I used real jalapeno pepper (3) but took out the seeds and membrane and although I love hot this was good for anyone...just perfect.  My guests loved it!  I made it the day before and put in the refrigerator and only popped it in the oven as guests were arriving...This is a KEEPER!

Everyone in my family LOVED this!  My family love spicy food, and they gobbled it up with garlic pita chips.  I also served tortilla chips, but they seemed to prefer the pita chips with it. text:
I'm giving this 5 stars based on my alterations.  I could not find a can of chopped jalapenos so I purchased the jar of pickled ones.  Not sure how the pickled jalapenos would taste I opted to put in 3 fresh chopped jalapenos.  Despite the fresh jalapenos and the can of chili peppers, the dip needed more bite to it so I added about a dozen of the pickled jalapenos and about a TBS of the juice from the jar.  I also added about a TBS of Romano cheese (I didn't have parmesan on hand) to the mixture.  After the dip was heated through, I added the bread crumbs (with some cheese mixed in) and broiled it until toasted on top.  It was delicious and everyone loved it!

text:
Ok, so I used a 4 oz can of chopped green chilies, chopped them finer. Then added a handful of fresh chilies, I like spice. I also topped it with the bread crumb and Parmesan cheese topping. I kept some of this mixture to the side and stuffed mushrooms with it. SO GOOD! I pulled out the stems to the mushrooms and sauteed them with a little red onion and mixed it with the cream cheese. I sauteed the whole mushrooms for a few minutes, then added the cheese mixture and baked in oven at 350 for five minutes. 

Delicious. Btw, this is my absolute favorite dip. I LOVED IT! I devoured it.

This dip is awesome! I made it for my son's birthday party and it was completely gone. I had lots of requests for this recipe.  I used hot green chiles, a 4oz can of diced jalapenos, 1 fresh jalapeno chopped, mixed in half of the parmesan cheese then topped with the remaining parmesan and topped that with panko bread crumbs. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wasn't as impressed as I thought I would be from the other reviews, but this is still a pretty good dip. I believe the problem was that I didn't have mayo so I used Miracle Whip instead. The Miracle Whip was kind of overpowering. When I make this again I will reduce the Miracle Whip and I might try using some sour cream in the mix too. Another thing I changed was I mixed some of the parmesan into the dip and put the rest on top. I agree with the other reviewers about increasing the amount of jalapenos. I was afraid to use more than the recipe called for but next time I will add a few more so it has more zip. I served with tortilla chips and pita chips. I preferred the tortilla chips but some preferred the pita chips - both were good. I will be keeping this recipe!

text:
I'm going to jump on the bandwagon... yes, this really IS that good and this easy.  I made it mostly as presented: just cut the amount of peppers in half, since I am not good with a lot of spices.  But even with that cut down, they still give this dip a wonderful flavor.  I also mixed some cheddar-jack cheese in with the parmesan on top, and added the Panko crumbs others have suggested.  I also sprinkled a little paprika on top for color.  Baked it for 20 min. at 450. My young adult son asked me yesterday if I could make some cheese dip just for the family.  This is so different than what we usually make, that I wasn't sure it would be what he had a taste for.  He took one taste and said, "Oh, yeah! This is exactly what I was after, I mean, it's better than I was after!"

text:
As good as everyone says.  This was completely gobbled up by about 6 people!  I actually messed up and broiled it and burnt the top when I cooked it so I had to scrape the top layer off and re-cover it with parmesan.  I actually liked it with just parmesan; the top was not a hard shell the way it was when I combined the parmesan with panko crumbs, but this might be because I only cooked it for about 5 mins with the parmesan (maybe adding the cheese on top near the end is a good idea).  I definitely recommend using all 4 oz of jalepenos, and I might try more next time.

I too baked this, using a pie plate that was sprayed with Pam, for the specified baking time & temp. There were a few changes. I used the Hellman's Mayo w/ olive oil which is what I had in my fridge. I used 1/2 cup of panko bread crumbs mixed with the 1 cup of FRESHLY grated parmesan and sprinkled that on top. SO GOOD!!!! I'm not too crazy about jalapeno poppers but I loved this dip & it had a nice, mellow kick (though two guys considered it more than enough of a kick). Served it with thinly sliced baguette that I broiled for a few minutes.

So good!  I do mix the parm w/ the bread crumbs, but I've found that it can be a lot of topping so I reduce it by about 1/3.  For extra spice, dice a fresh jalapeno and stir into the mixture.  I also will slice (but seed) a couple add'l jalapeno's and place them on top of the spread before the topping mixture.  I recommend the baking option.

This recipe is really great - its quick and easy, very flexible (you can substitute fresh jalapenos for canned, or cheddar for parmesan, etc), and a real crowd pleaser. text:
I took this to a potluck and smiled while I watched everyone stand there and devour it. I'm not much of a cook, but this couldn't have been more simple to prepare. I couldn't find diced jalapeno peppers but used 1 can chopped chilies and 1 can hot chopped chilies which I did not drain. (they didn't seem to have that much liquid) Pefect! I read many reviews and followed the advice given. I  grated my own parmesan and mixed about a 1/2 cup panko bread crumbs to sprinkle on top. Baked at 350 for 30 mins and served with sliced baguettes. My husband has now requested this for a potluck at his job next week. This is a keeper!

Excellent!  Made for Christmas Eve and it was gone so quick that my husband complained he didn't get any.  I subbed 1/2 of the mayo with sour cream and grated fresh parm. cheese.  Mixed 1/2 with the dip and 1/2 with panko and baked it.  Everyone loved it!  I also used 2 fresh jalapenos instead of canned.  You could taste it but there wasn't alot of heat.  Next time I'll try 2-1/2 to 3 peppers instead just to kick it up a little.  Served with triscuits, sliced baguette and totstitoes.  The tostitoes are by far the best choice with this dip IMO.  Thanks for submitting this wonderful recipe!! Will make again and again

text:
The men stood around the dish for the 20 minutes it took them to completely inhale every last bit of this dip.  It's insanely good and authentic.  My only changes just to be a little healthier, I did 1/2 cup mayo 1/2 cup sour cream, chopped 6 fresh jalpenos, omitted the greens chilies (don't like the flavor).  I also added a little mozzerella cheese to the mixture for the stringy cheese effect.  I've served with melba chips, french bread (untoasted) and club cracker dipping sticks.  The bread is the best but it goes well with all three.  Everyone loves this dip. It's a keeper for sure!

This is a wonderful appetizer recipe.  It is so delicious and couldn't be easier to make too!  I added 1/2 cup panko crumbs with grated parm on top before putting in the oven at 375 for 1/2 hour.  I served it with baguette slices, which was good, but next time I will serve with baguette slices, pretzels, and triscuits, I think the last two taste great with this dip.  This is a perfect football party dip but was good enough for a ladies' holiday party for me!

Easy, easy, easy and great flavor.  I've made it 2x so far.  The 2nd time I wasn't as careful measuring the mayo and ended up adding a little too much. I also used 1 cup of freshly grated parmesan and 1/2 cup of Panko.  Nice addition of flavor and texture to the crust.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I've never had jalapeno poppers but this was fantastic. I did mix the parmesan with bread crumbs as suggested by some. As I was preparing the dip, I taste tested and could not find any flvor or heat. As a reult I added a second can of green chiles and the majority of my 7oz can of jalapenos. Go figure, the baking is what brings out the flavor and heat. My dip was extremely spicey! I didn't receive complaints but it did catch someone off guard who had a big mouthful for the first bite. However, the dip was devoured. I'd add just a scoop few jalapenos next time but I'd definitely add more than the recipe calls for. This is a keeper and will be made many more times!

text:
I love stuffed Jalapenos, so this recipe intrigued me. Could I actually have the flavor without the mess of making them?  Yes!  This is great!  I took it to a Halloween Party and it was gobbled up w/ many people asking for the recipe. To make= I blended the cream cheese (lite) and mayo (lite) together until smooth w/ hand mixer.  I added 4 oz. of EACH jalapenos & green chilies.  I then stirred in the parmesean cheese.   I baked @ 350 for 30 min.  Cannot wait to make this again!!

text:
we've made this several times now, changing it up for perfection.  here's my advice.. ~it does taste best with toasted french baguette slices so don't bother adding breadcrumbs to the recipe..they failed to improve the spread.   ~use half grated parm, and the other half fresh shredded ~double your jalepenos if you want some heat ~better yet, to really taste like poppers use fresh jalapenos.  i recommend 4 and you can take out all or some seeds to tame the heat ~bake at 350 for 30 mins ~used reduced fat cream cheese and mayo and it was still fantastic!!!

text:
We absolutely LOVE this dip! I do add extra jalapenos for a little more kick, but it's fantastic just as written. Sometimes I put it into mini phyllo cups, top w/ panko crumbs and parm. cheese and bake until browned. Everyone loves it either way it's served! I don't microwave it, I put it in a 350 degree oven for about 20 mins. or so, until brown and bubbly. This dip is a staple at all our get-togethers! Thanks for posting. :)

I made this for the first time last week for a pot luck,made it again three days later for Father's day, everyone LOVED this recipe, they could not get enough.Came back to work today and all of my coworkers kept asking for the recipe.This is FABULOUS!!! I always get my recipes from this website and this recipe has by far had the best reviews. Consensus from work and at my BBQ is that the dip is best with warm bread, honestly though when we ran out of that  people were using anything they could get their hands on to dip in it. Followed other reviews did 1/2 cup mayo,1/2 sour cream,added cheddar cheese to the mixture,topped with bread crumbs and parmesan cheese then sprayed with butter flavored pam and baked for 30 mins.This dip will be what I take everywhere from now on.  THANK YOU SO MUCH DENISE!!!:)

text:
This is a very good dip to serve when you want to put it out on the table and forget about it. It is awesome when it is warm, but still very tasty when it reaches room temperature! As suggested, I used shredded parmesan cheese instead of grated, sprinkled a little Italian seasoned bread crumbs on top (don‚Äôt really know if it was necessary), and baked it in the oven instead of microwaving. It wasn‚Äôt great as far as presentation goes, but that sure didn‚Äôt stop my guests from chowing it down. Next time I may place a few slices of colorful bell peppers or a sprig of parsley on top after baking to add some color to the dish.  Definitely serve with French baguettes. I say baguettes because you need two to finish off the dip. One is not enough.  I sliced the baguettes and lightly toasted them in the oven. I tried it with a cracker and it wasn‚Äôt as good. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This is wonderful.  5 stars is not enough for this great recipe. I made it to take to a friend's house and 4 of us ate almost the entire thing.  I did use some of the changes suggested by others.  I used 1/2 mayo - 1/2 sour cream.  I could not find canned jalapeno peppers so i used the sliced ones in the jar & chopped them.  I increased them amount to 2/3 cup.  I used a Mexican blend cheese instead of the parmesan and stirred it into the spread.  Topped it with toasted bread crumbs with about 1/4 cup Romano cheese.  I had to travel with this so i put it in a crock pot and right before serving put the toasted bread crumbs on top,  It was Heavenly.  This is a real keeper

text:
Haha, I made this for my family and they completely desmembered the bowl in 20 minutes flat (they ignored the fact that they were burning their mouths because it was hot, that's how good it was!). I made the "French Baguettes" recipe from this site as the bread. I formed it into long thin rolls so when it was baked and sliced, I got nice medallion-like slices of bread, perfect for scooping the spread. I did stir in some parmesan cheese as well as sprinkle it on the top. I used panko crumbs to add crunch. It turned out well. I microwaved the whole bowl till hot (3 or 4 minutes), then broiled it until the crumbs were nice and browned. The heating procedure took about 10 minutes total, making this a very easy and very fast snack.

text:
Wow, this really does taste like a jalapeno popper.  Per the suggestion of other reviews, I also doubled the jalapenos, and used fresh shaved parmesan and 1/2 c. panko bread crumbs for the topping.  It was delicious! Beware, however - the amount of "heat" you get will depend on the peppers you used.  I used the jarred "pickled" jalapenos (the ones you use on nachos) and this dip came out EXTREMELY hot (and trust me, my tastebuds are tough; I love hot, spicy food!) Using these peppers, I probably should have stuck with the recipe and only used 2 oz.  Only those who can tolerate really spicy food (like me) could eat this at the New Year's Eve party I took it to.  While you may need to play around with the peppers to find the right "temperature" for you and your guests, it's definitely a recipe you'll want to try.  Yummy and so easy, too!

text:
This was SO good!  I decided, despite the reviews of others with tips on enhancing the recipe, to go with the exact recipe as written.  It turned out absolutely perfectly.  Tasted just like a jalapeno popper, even with the Parmesan cheese, which was freshly grated.  Served it with slices of french baguette.  The only thing I did differently, was to bake it at 300 F for half an hour in a glass 9x9 square baking dish.  As it cooled down, I just popped it back into the microwave to re-heat it.  Everyone loved it and asked for the recipe.  My suggestion is, do not stray from the original recipe until you've at least tried it.  I wouldn't change a thing!

Everyone absolutely loves this recipe -- served with Wheat Thins.  I have made it three times and let everyone know its from Allrecipes.com. text:
I never really review recipes but this one is fantastical!!!!  My hubby and I ate this for dinner last night LOL  I am trying it before I bring it to a Superbowl party this Sunday, and it will be a hit for sure.  I did add more jalapenos and chilies and I did use the breadcrumbs.  I mixed a cup of breadcrumbs with a tablespoon or so of olive oil, so they were not too wet.  I used parmesan and asiago cheeses sparingly on top.  Also, I sliced french bread and toasted in oven right after I took the spread out, and cooked them for about 3 minutes, they were crunchy enough to withstand the spread but not so crunchy that they tore the roof of your mouth up. I LOVE THIS RECIPE!!!!!!

This is so easy and so awesome! I've made it twice now- once for a Halloween party and again for a party last night. I've never reviewed a recipe but after my friend jokingly proposed to me after tasting this dip, I thought I should let everyone know how good this recipe is! I used 1 1/2 fresh jalapenos without the seeds. I think I could have used 2, I like it a bit more spicy. I put it in a pie dish and baked it in the oven at 350 for like 10 or 15 mins. This way the parmesean gets a little brown. The recipe doesn't need to be modified. The first time I made it I used cheddar cheese and bread crumbs on top and it wasn't as good. Looooveee it.

text:
I used a whole 4 oz. can of diced Green Chilis and an whole 4 oz. can of Diced Jalapeno peppers.  The recipe only calls for 2 oz. of Jalapeno peppers but I didn't want to waste the other 1/2 of the can so I dumped in the entire can.  Boy did it turn out spicy!  YUM, we love spicy!  Served it with cubed Sour Dough French Bread and Corn Chips.  It was a big hit for New Years Eve!  I'm thnking of spreading the left overs on french bread slices and broiling them till browned and bubbly.  Served up with a bowl of Tomato Soup for dinner it should keep us toasty warm on the inside while the winter storms rage outside.  Quick and easy dinner on a weeknight and a great way to use up the leftovers!

This dip is wonderful - I get so many compliments - my only alteration is I use about 1/2 of the mayo because I think the mayo makes it too rich - still very good/tasty as is, but just a little too heavy for my liking. text:
Great way to use up garden jalapenos!  I add 6 or so depending on hotness, finely chopped.  Use fresh Parmesan cheese; the veggie peeler does quick work of shaving it down and it will add creamy, smoothness to the dish making it more dip like and less spread like. Make ahead, too, so the peppers have time to flavor the dish.
I serve with soft pretzel bites.  Everyone loves this!

The Bread Crumbs are a must!  It does give it that popper flavor. I heavily sprinkled with grated Parmesan,(out of the jar)and then the crumbs. I used only fresh Jalapeno seeds and cartilage I had leftover from another recipe.  I used the 7 oz Fire Roasted can of diced Green Chiles and added half of a chopped red onion. userID:
11028683
Display Name:
winelight
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3648295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Made it for the NYE party and it was a hit. The crowd I was serving was very health-conscious, so there was about half left over, but everyone gave me lots of compliments on it. 
The only thing I'd have to say about it is that the stated amount of jalapenos is definitely too little if you have spice-lovers in your crowd. The can I had was 7.75 oz, so I'd measured in exactly 2 oz first but realized that wasn't going to be nearly enough. I knew that my crowd loved hot/spicy food, so I just dumped the ENTIRE can in and that made a nice difference, visually and texturally.
I did put freshly grated parmesan cheese over it, followed by breadcrumbs and then baked it for 30 minutes. The breadcrumbs didn't toast entirely, so perhaps try the broiler for a toasted top.
I served it with the smaller Triscuit triangles.
Canned jalapenos are milder than fresh, apparently. 
But the dip definitely tastes like jalapeno poppers.
I took the advice from other reviewers and melted the leftovers into scrambled eggs the next morning and it was delicious.
Great recipe!

text:
Amazing recipe! It was a huge thanksgiving hit with everyone.  
I combined a bunch of advice from everyone and came up with the following:
No chilies
5 fresh, chopped jalapenos (had some heat but not too much)
Reduced fat mayo
Fresh parm I grated myself mixed with 1/2 cup Panko and spread on top.
I baked for 20 minutes on 300 then broiled for a minute to get it crispy on top. I could have baked it longer as it wasn't SUPER hot in the middle so that was my one suggestion.
Otherwise amazing-will be my new quick go to!

Display Name:
pizzalisa
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe for a beer tasting party I attended last night.  I was a bit skeptical about how this was going to  taste given such few ingredients and the ease of making it.  It turned out pretty darn tasty.  Here's what I did and didn't do to it.  I forgot to drain the can of green chilies and jalapenos.  The dip consistency was great.  So, this recipe just got easier.  Then, I used most of the can of jalapenos which was a 4 oz. can rather than a 2 oz. can.  That was the perfect amount of heat for me.  I also mixed in some fresh grated parmesan and then microwaved as suggested.  Then I topped it off with a mixture of parmesan and panko bread crumbs as others have done before me.  I broiled it in my toaster oven to get it lightly browned and viola!  In my opinion, the best thing to serve with this dip is thinly sliced french bread.  I didn't toast the bread, just sliced it.  The crowd devoured it!  All gone!  I will definitely make this again.  Thanks for the easy and delish recipe!

text:
It was gone within minutes.  I made extra but next time I will double it!  I dumped everything in the crock pot in less than five minutes and stirred it once before I served it.  I doubled the jalapenos as others suggested (I used the kind in the jar, not fresh, chopped in my mini food processor) and used cheddar cheese instead of Parmesan and served with Club crackers.  I thought the mayo might be too much but it was not.  I made this in an emergency when I needed to bring something cheap and easy to feed a huge group of hungry people.  If I'd had more time I would have added bacon, next time!

Display Name:
martyrthisthat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/445599.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I added bread crumbs, used only 1/2 cup of mayo and used 9 whole jalapenos canned (finely diced by hand).  I baked the dip, then served in a crock-pot.

I did use a lot of jalapenos.  This was the perfect amount of spicy for me, but some guests thought it was too spicy.  I would not suggest using a crock pot because the oil tends to separate rather quickly.  While the dip still tastes really good the mouth feel and presentation are kind of gross.  This is obviously from the constant heat.


I think letting the dip sit over night would help to combine flavors a lot better.  I probably wouldn't bother with breadcrumbs again.  Pair with some sort of garlic chip/cracker/pretzel.

country:
None
text:
I found this recipe when my sister was having a small gathering and just wanted to serve snacks. I read her the recipe (since we live almost 2000 miles apart) and she was a little skeptical about it... to spicy for guests, etc. But she decided to make it anyway and have a couple other things non-spicy. 
She said that this dip went so fast that she and her husband didn't even get any. So about 3 days later she called me from her grocery store and asked me to look up the ingredients so she could make sure she had all of it to make up a batch just for the two of them.
After that I've made it several times for family gatherings. My step-daughter's family hovered around the bowl of dip and ate all the tortilla chips - even the crumbs - until the dip was gone. 
I can't say how good it is from personal experience as I am allergic to cheese, but I'm rating this on the raves I got from my guests and the many times I was asked for the recipe. Thanks for sharing!

wow, this will definitely be a mainstay on my party food menu! Tasted just like the real thing, but in a much more enjoyable and decadent dip! I took others' advice and doubled the jalapenos to 4 oz, which made it really quite hot - definitely something you should add or subtract to your liking.  I mixed about 1/2 c panko breadcrumbs w the 1 cup FRESH grated pram, and baked uncovered at 375 for 30 mins.  Produced a golden crust that just put this dip over the edge!

country:
None
text:
I made this dip with the following changes.  Used 1/2 cup mayo, 1/2 cup sour cream, 8 fresh jalape√±os seeded and deveined.  I pureed these ingredients with the cream cheese using a hand blender and put in a pie plate and covered with the bread crumbs mixed with shredded cheddar cheese and used a tbls of olive oil to moisten the bread crumb mixture.  Baked until bubbly in 350 degree oven.  I couldn't believe how much it tasted like the poppers.  I will definitely make again.  The dip was not in the least bit spicy.  So, if you want something spicy then probably add some cayenne pepper or something like that.  We used Tostito chips as well as baked french bread slices.  It really is very yummy.  Please give it a try!

country:

text:
Made this recipe as written the first time and it was good.  Made it again and modified the ingredients a bit which really enhanced the flavor.  I replaced mayo with sour cream which has more of a tang to it.  I also incorporated about a cup of shredded sharp cheddar to the dip  Finally, I mixed melted butter, bread  crumbs, garlic powder, salt and pepper and spread it evenly over the top of the dip.  Poppers are usually breaded, so this step makes it taste like the real deal. :)  10 minutes before the dip comes out of the oven, I also sprinkle a bit of cheddar on the top and allow it to melt.  Enjoy! Served this with cubed rye bread and guests literally wanted to lick the plate. Everyone asked for the recipe...so thanks for postng!

text:
Made this and it was excellent!  Just remember the longer it sits the spicier it will get.  I made it a few hours in advance and at first I thought it just tasted like cream cheese but I decided to let it sit and give it a chance.  I tasted it a few hours later before putting it in the oven and it had nice flavor and I nice kick.  I followed others' advice and I mixed the parmesan cheese with about 1/2 cup or so of Panko bread crumbs and put it in 350F oven until the bread crumbs/cheese were golden brown (about 20 minutes). Definitely serve with toasted bread rounds.  Will make it again for sure!

text:
Delicious.  Solid 5 stars for me.  Stick to what the submitter said.  I used real parm & added a whole 'can' of jalapenos (strong jalapeno flavor but not too hot).  Sprinkled panko & parm on top.  Heated in 450 oven, along w/a pan of lightly buttered baguette 1/4" slices.  Lightly browned the baguette for about 5 mins & dip about 15-20 mins. I really like this dip, an alter to my usual spinach dip.

text:
Love this dip & everyone who has had it loves it too. I have made it the way the recipe calls for & I have also made it with some substitutions & everyone has loved both ways...
Substitutions consist of 1 cup Plain Greek Yogurt in place of the Mayonnaise for a healthier version. Also using fresh jalapenos in addition to the canned ones. Also adding some of the juice from the jalapenos also adds a nice kick.
Adding mixed cheeses also was a substitution I tried... Pepper Jack, Parmesan, Cheddar, etc...

As a side note, there were just as many who favored the healthier version as did the original version.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This spread really is delicious! Even if you do not care for jalapenos (as I don't), the dip is fabulous. I just had to review this one; mostly to let you know that BACON in this recipe is wonderful. I know the original submitter mentioned that you would think it would be good, but it's not -- so I just wanted to let all you bacon lovers out there know that it is VERY good! Be sure to cook the bacon until very crisp and either chop finely or throw in the food processor for a few pulses. I actually put both my bacon and fresh jalapenos in the food processor to avoid any large chunks, which my guests found unappealing the first time I made it. Give the bacon a try. I think you'll like it! Also, whoever mentioned making it ahead of time and resting in the fridge is brilliant - so much better the next day! And even cold!

WOW! Addictive! It's creamy, spicy, and to die for! I did double the jalapenos(I like spicy), and add a tsp of garlic powder, but frankly if I hadn't, it would have been just as grand. After eating some of it, I did end up mixing the Parmesan into the dip, rather than just leaving it on top, and it didn't ruin the texture at all. Try it for your next party, or just for your own family's enjoyment. A smaller crock-pot would work wonderful for this recipe if you want to keep it warm for your guests.

text:
This is terrific! I used all jalapenos and omitted the green chilies. I also mixed some shredded montery jack cheese into the dip with a little extra mayo and about a tblsp of juice from the jalapeno jar. I topped it with both parmesan and montery jack cheeses mixed with a little panko bread crumbs and then heated it in the oven. We used toasted french bread drizzeled with Tuscan olive oil and a touch of garlic for dipping. A new family favorite!

text:
Very delicious dip!  I loved it!  I thought it had a perfect heat. I cut the cream cheese, mayo and parmesan cheese in half due to making it for 2 people (and we still had a lot w/doing that).  I used 3 oz of chilies, 2 fresh jalapenos chopped up, about 2-3 tbs of jar jalapenos chopped up and about a 1/4 cup of shredded cheddar cheese mixed all together.  As recommended I mixed the parmesan cheese w/ 1 tbs bread crumbs, but I only had roasted garlic and savory spices bread crumbs.   Baked at 375 for 30 minutes and then broiled for about a minute to brown the cheese a little more.  Ate w/tortilla chips and triscuits.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the following adjustments per other reviewers suggestions.  2/3 c maynnaise, 1/3 c sour cream.  I used 6 fresh from the garden jalapenos.  I used half cheddar cheese and half parm.  I put some cheddar into the mixture and then I put the cheese on top.  I sprinkled regular bread crumbs on top of the cheese and microwaved for 3 minutes.  AHHHH-mazing!  We LOVED it.  It wasn't too spicy, so if you really want a kick, I'd suggest using even more jalapenos.

text:
This was great! My son and I were looking for recipes using the jalapenos we've been growing in the garden. We made this with a little change. Instead of using the canned chiles and canned jalapenos, I seeded and chopped 7 medium jalapenos (we like it spicy). I made up the cream cheese, mayo, jalapeno mixture ahead of time, then refrigerated it for a few hours. I then topped it with the cheese and we baked it. Sooo Good!

text:
I had seen this recipe mentioned many times on the recipe buzz, when someone is looking for an appetizer to take to a party, and just tried it. I surprisingly had all of the ingredients in the house, but used the calculate button to make 8 servings, or 1 cup, to test it. I would use a shallow dish as the parmesan cheese on top really adds to the dip and I think it would be better spread out. It is so quick to make in the microwave, but I wonder if it wouldn't have been better in the oven. This though makes a very quick and easy dip for a pot luck or party.

text:
This recipe is very easy and tastes exactly like jalapeno poppers...except for the Parmesan cheese sprinkled on top.  The Parmesan cheese has an overwhelming initial flavor that I think could be omitted from the recipe.  The leftovers are easy to use also, top triscuit crackers with a spoonful of the dip and bake at 350 for about 15-20 minutes! The triscuit crackers crumble when you bite into them and taste just like poppers with a crunch breading!

text:
This was a big hit for the football Sunday crowd. The entire pan was gone by halftime. I used fresh jalapenos (about 6) instead of canned and also added 1/2 cup Panko bread crumbs to the cheese. It was phenomenal. Real mayo (Hellmann's is my favorite) keeps it creamy. Also, the Parmesan cheese needs to be an actual block that is shredded. The fake stuff in the green can probably would have killed the recipe. I'm not sure about replacing some of the mayo with sour cream. I didn't do it that way, so I won't say it doesn't work. However, I can say that the recipe as is does work quite well.

5 stars is not enough for this dip - this recipe is to DIE for - I am a huge appetizer fan and try new recipes all the time.  I have made it about 10 times so far and everyone asks for the recipe.  I did add a few extras - I added some shredded cheddar and real bacon bits to the mixture.  I also used fresh jalapenos - about 3 chopped.  If the recipe is not hot enough - cuz you never know whith japs - I chop fresh ones and put them on the top after it comes out of the oven.  I will be making this recipe for years to come - yum yum!!!

text:
Seriously addicting dip.  I've had to give out the recipe on several occasions already.  I've baked it and microwaved it and been satisfied either way.  I tried just using just the parmesan on top and I also tried adding panko crumbs to the parmesan on top as someone suggested.  Either way, the top gets a little too tough when it cools off a little.  I've since started to simply add the parmesan to the cream cheese mixture.  Problem solved!

This was excellent and so easy.  The only changes I made was added 1 cup of parm to the dip and then more on top and baked in the oven for 1/2 hour. text:
only with these changes: Bake 400 for 20 min. The mayo makes it bake nicely.  Microwaving it is no comparison. Used freshly grated parm and mixed throughout. Used about 7 oz drained diced jalapenos instead of 2 oz. Added about 2 cups mild cheddar throughout & reserved some for the top. Topping:  combine about 1/3 to 1/2 cp bread crumbs, 2 tblsp melted butter, and remaining cheddar. Sprinkle on top.

I have made this several times now to rave reviews and requests for the recipe.  I have been adding the entire 4 oz of chopped jalapeno for a nice, but not overly, spicy-ness. The first time i made this recipe it had a strong mayo flavor and tasted like it was missing something. I made some changes the second time. I added another 2 ounces of jalapeno peppers cut the mayo to 1/4 cup and added 1/2 cup of sour cream. i also halved the Parmesan cheese and added 1/2 cup mozzarella and then mixed it with panko bread crumbs before putting it on top of the spread and baked it. the second time it was awesome. But as the recipe is written i wouldnt give it more than the two stars

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times. Every party I go to I am expected to bring this dip. I have even made it while camping. It is an absolute show stopper. I do make couple of changes. #1 I do not use the green chilies. #2 I use a 4 ounce can of jalapenos (I like it spicy) When I initially used this recipe I mixed the parmesan in instead of sprinkling it on top. It turned out so good I havent changed it. I find that using a small crock pot works well to keep it hot during potlucks and dinner parties. I use sourdough baggette slices but people seem to use just about anything to dip into it.  I wouldn't suggest using reduced fat or fat free mayo or cream cheese-I had a friend do it and it was less than perfection. This recipe is fattening, enjoy it, thats what its supposed to be!!!

text:
I thought this was great, though I did slightly alter the recipe. I halved the recipe (just 2 of us, and this was still MORE than enough) and instead of using 1/2 cup of mayo, I used a tablespoon of light mayo and a tablespoon of light sour cream. My cream cheese wasn't softened, so I stuck it in the microwave for 45 seconds- everything mixed together smoothly.  I also added a bit of shredded cheddar cheese to the top.  We served it with tortilla chips and I had to take the dish away, for fear that my husband would eat almost an entire package of cream cheese in one sitting.

text:
This was one of the best spreads I have ever tasted! I don't believe you can find anyone who doesn't love this, not unless they don't like jalapenos. I don't like it when others try to do their own thing to the recipes on here and then try rate it...I know I'm not the only one. Follow EXACTLY what Denise says, even using the shredded parmesan...NOT GRATED! I have not tried the microwave version, nor would I,  I only use that to heat things up- not to cook :) Everyone I have made this for wants the recipe, it's just that GREAT! I too used the whole 4oz. can of jalapenos like Denise does, we like the heat--isn't that what a jalapeno consists of?? The baked version is the only way to go! THANK YOU Denise, this is so AMAZING! To Katie, asking if anyone has made it the night before, I haven't but I can't see any reason why you couldn't! The green chiles and jalapenos are drained so there shouldn't be any worry, BUT this is so quick to throw together that it really doesn't need to be assembled the night before, then again, I don't know your circumstances.

text:
This was the hit of our Christmas appetizers. Based on other reviews, I used 3 cans of jalapeno's (our family likes spicy), I mixed 1/2 cup of panko bread crumbs into the parmesan topping, I baked at 350 for 20 minutes without the topping, then another 10 minutes with the topping.  The result, a crisp crust atop ooey gooey deliciousness.  It really does taste like jalepeno poppers.

text:
YUM! I made this for a baby shower. It was absolutely the hit of the party - for real. Lots of people complimented it & wanted the recipe. I used fresh jalapenos from my garden. I used 1/2 c sour cream & 1/2 c mayo. I added shredded cheese to the cream cheese & on top. I mixed the parmesan w/bread crumbs. Baked it at 300 degrees for 30 min or so. I served it w/Roasted Veggie Ritz crackers but it was also good w/chips. It was awesome & I will make it the same way soon! Thank You Denise!! - Update 5/23/11: I have made this dip many, many times.. It's what I make for almost every get-together that I go to. I have people ask me to bring it & EVERY time I take it somewhere, someone asks me for the recipe. I still love it very much!!

text:
This is SUCH a hit whenever I take it to any event. I change just a couple of things, I add 2 small cans of the green chiles drained, and 3/4 of a can of jalapenos drained. I also include 3/4 a bag of parmesan cheese while mixing. After putting it in a dish, I sprinkle the remaining 1/4 cheese on top and pop it in a 350 degree oven for about 20 minutes or until it's bubbling. (So much better than the microwave in my opinion) :) Happy cooking!

text:
While I loved the dip - I only assigned 4 stars because it really needs some additions to be 5 stars.  I followed the advice of some other reviewers and added more jalapeno peppers - I basically doubled the amount of jalapenos and green chiles.  I also added about a cup of Cheddar Cheese to the mix to give the dip a little more substance.  I did not microwave - I cooked in the oven at 350 degrees for about 25-30 minutes.  I served with frito scoops and round tortilla chips so people had a choice.  Everyone loved it and several people asked for the recipe.

text:
This is my favorite party dip and people always request it. I warm cream cheese in microwave, add cheese and other ingredients, and warm again until soft enough to stir together.  Then, I refrigerate for a few hours if possible.  I serve it in a fried taco shell bowl and sprinkle panko crumbs on top.  I serve it with both bread cubes and chips.  It is delicious baked too!  I always use light ingredients and BE SURE TO USE MAYO!

I was amazed at how good this turned out.  The recipe didn't sound like it would taste that good, but there were so many good reviews that I had to try it. text:
OUTSTANDING!!! I've made this several times and with several different cheeses now... the best way I've had it is using fresh Parmigiano/Reggiano mix and bake for sure with the Panko topping. I've made it with Monterey Jack Cheese and only mild chilies, it was very bland but if you're in a pinch it works. I found that hot sauce helped give it a little more of a controlled kick if your worried about the spiciness.  ***Update*** Kraft now makes a grated Parmigiano/Reggiano mix that works really well in this.

4 stars as is...maybe? I made a lot of changes. First I halved the cream cheese to one 8oz box. I added 2 cans of diced green chilies, and 1 fresh, chopped jalapeno pepper. city:
