region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this dip, it is awesome.  My favorite dip from this website, and I love the warm artichoke and spinach dip and also the dill cucumber toasties.  Make it as is, no panko/bread crumbs, as suggested, and no baking, just microwaving.  It is definitely not spicy.  If you love spicy, then here is what you do [NOTE: this modification is if you are making 1/2 a recipe]: Take a 4 oz can of diced green chilies and a 4 oz. can of diced jalapenos.  Drain both. Combine in a microwave safe dish.  Return 2 oz. (half a can) of the combination to one of the cans and refrigerate for later.  Add 1 cream cheese, 1/2 cup mayo, and 1/2 cup grated Parmesan.  Mix and microwave.  AWESOME.

text:
This was a hit. I used fresh japs, omitted the chilies, used half sour cream and half mayo. I also didn't serve as a dip. I cut a loaf of french bread in half (long ways) and spread the dip on there, then topped with the bread crumbs and cheese and popped it in the oven until the cheese on top was really melted.  My family was eating the falloff on the pan I baked it on!  Also I had to stick toothpicks in the bread to make it stand right, and bake on top. Apparently I pinched the loaf too hard while I was cutting. It kept falling over. :)

text:
I made this spread yesterday to bring to a family party and it was a huge hit! After I completed the dip as per the recipe(minus the parmesan),I put a cover of shredded sharp cheddar over the top followed by a layer of panko bread crumbs.  I baked it for 30 minutes at 375 and then garnished with fresh jalapeno slices and some cilantro.  I toasted thin slices of french bread and it was to die for! This will definitely be a new staple on my appetizer list. A+++

text:
Fantastic! Cant go wrong with this - great crowd pleaser.  Took this to a family bday party and it was swarmed. I slightly adjusted after reading many of the reviews. Used 4 oz. of jalapenos, used fresh shredded parmesan cheese and crushed maybe about 10 Ritz crackers and mixed that with the cheese. Put in a 8 inch pie plate, topped with the Ritz/cheese mix and backed at 350 for about 35 minutes. Did serve with toasted homemade italian bread. Was definitely a "bread" dip and not a "tortilla chip" dip. Also, used lite mircale whip and still tasted great! Thanks for the recipe!

I love this recipe! Jalapeno Poppers are one of my favorite appetizers when eating out.  But I don't like the calories associated with them.  I have made this recipe with low fat using fat-free cream cheese, and low-fat.  I also use a whole wheat or toasted multi-grain baguette (pop a few in the toaster for an individual fun meal!).  I added a bit of bread crumbs to the top also, as recommended by others to keep the parm cheese from crusting over.

text:
I had my doubts about such a simple recipe but this was a big hit! The dish was scraped clean early into the evening and was the only empty appetizer dish on the table. 
I cut jalepeno slices and placed them around the edge of the dish so those who wanted more pop could help themselves and baked it to brown the cheese. 
Got a loaf of french bread, had them cut it at the bakery then cut those slices in half, misted them with spray oil and toasted them under the broier.
Had a bit of trouble getting the cream cheese and mayo smooth (might not have let the cream cheese soften enough?) but was able to whisk it smooth where the spoon had failed. 
Awesome recipe, Thanks!

text:
Excellent recipe!  This can be made ahead of time. Because I refrigerated it (minus the topping), it needed more cooking time.  I covered it with foil and baked it in the oven for about twenty minutes.  I then took the foil off and then added the topping(so it would not burn). I used twice the jalapenos.  I also used Panko bread crumbs mixed with shredded parmesean cheese.  I did spray the topping with a few sprays of Pam cooking spray.  If you like jalapenos and cream cheese, you'll love this recipe.  I think this recipe is best if not altered.

text:
WOW this was really great!  It really tasted exactly like poppers.  I pretty much followed directions, however; I could not find canned diced jalapenos, I bought a 7 oz can of pickled jalapenos, diced them and added.  I did not feel it was hot at all so I added 5 fresh diced jalapenos, still really no heat so next time I will add some of the seeds.  I used the green chilies, 1/2 c miracle whip and 1/2 c sour cream.  Added half the grated cheese to the mix and the other half to the top with the panko bread crumbs sprayed with pam (for bit of browning) and popped in the oven at 350 for 20-30 min.  Served with toasted bread and ritz.

I took this to a Halloween party & it was a big hit!! I had 2 ladies almost tackle me for the recipe! text:
This was so simple to assemble it should be ILLEGAL!

I wanted to get it ready for tonight, for when my husband got home. Jalapeno Poppers are one of his favorite foods ever, and I've been wanting to make this ever since I saw it on the site.

Only thing different I did was throw the 
peppers in the blender with a bit of mayo, blend until smooth and then add it to the spread ingredients. Made for a more uniform jalapeno flavor. I snuck a bit out for myself to try before he got to it and boy, is that good! I added a little Frank's to mine, just for more kick.

This is going to be a regular in this house for sure!

THE BEST TASTING, EASIEST DIP IN THE WORLD! Next to no prep time, no need to chill first. Super Easy & Delicious!! I nuked is for 3 minutes when I got to my party & then put it under the broiler till it turned brown. Served it with Melba Toast. It was the hit of the party!

text:
I made this last night to take to a last-minute barbeque.  I only had half an hour after getting home from work and luckily this was just as fast to make as everyone said it would be.  It turned out excellent and got lots of compliments! I only made two teeny little changes and that was to add the bread crumbs on top and split my parmesan by mixing half grated into the mix and then the other half fresh shredded on top of the bread crumbs.  I usually have a somewhat liberal hand with jalapenos and this was spicy, but not too spicy for everyone to enjoy.  I served with baguette bread that I sliced and stuck under the broiler on the top rack just long enough to lightly toast it so that it was strong enough to stand up to the thick dip, but still a bit chewy.  Thanks for such a great fast and tasty dip!

My guests shamelessly mowed right through this dip....it's like they couldn't stay away from it.

I made it early in the day and chilled it to let flavors blend. I used jalepenos from a jar and probably more than the recipe called for. text:
Wow!  This was delicious and so beyond easy.  I served this with the Ritz crackers that are pretzel on one side and cracker on the other and it was perfect.  I was sort of concerned that this wouldn't really taste like a popper without crunchy outside.  The crackers added the perfect crunch to this without adding any extra steps to make a top on the dip.  I love that you can just stir this together in under 5 minutes, pop it in the fridge until you are ready to serve it, then just pop it in the microwave for 3 minutes, open a bag of crackers and you have wonderful homemade appetizer.  This is perfect for parties since you don't have to do any last minute prep.  Also, once it cools off it still tastes great and still looks appealing.

This recipe is seriously unbelievable. Trust the recipe. Don't go adding stuff to it, it's unlikely you're going to make it much better, if at all. Also, when microwaving, it's okay if it bubbles a lot and looks like it's overcooking. It's not. just stir it up when it's done. It blends the flavors, otherwise you just kind of end up eating spicy cream cheese.

text:
I was very skeptical of this recipe especially when I scoured the grocery store looking for "canned" jalapenos.  So I bought a 12 oz jar of pickled jalapenos and a 4 oz can of diced green chiles.  I drained the jalapenos and put about 1/2 the jar in the food processor to chop them.  Mixed as directed, scooped it into a 9" pie plate, topped with real Parm cheese and sprinkled panko bread crumbs on top and baked 375 for about 30 minutes or until nicely browned.  Even out of the oven, I was worried it wouldn't be good but BOY was I wrong! Tastes just like a popper and perfect amount of heat to it!  It got rave reviews!

text:
This dip is a big hit at every party I have taken it to.  I modify it depending on who the dip is for.  If they don't like spicy, I make it as written.  If they are a little more adventurous, I double the jalapenos.  Either way it is delicious.  Serve in a small crock pot to keep warm.  Sometimes I use Parmesan and Romano cheese mix.

userID:
3822325
Display Name:
ts_recipes
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
5 stars for the flavor profile. Super easy to put together and my dish is always scraped clean at parties.

I do have recommendations which others have also highlighted:
1. Do not use a whole cup of mayo - reduce to 1/2 or 3/4 cup. When you use 1 cup too much oil can come out when baking.

2. Bake it! It really helps develop the flavors and gives the top a nice color. I like using a 9X13 pyrex so there's more surface area for the topping.

3. Sprinkle panko breadcrumbs mixed with parmesan on top before baking! I put 6 oz of parmesan in the mixture and about 3 oz on top mixed with panko.

4. I use more jalapenos than it states here, and the kind in a jar... about 5 tablespoons chopped up with a little bit of the jarred liquid. If you use the slices meant for nachos it's not very spicy but has good flavor. For an added kick, use the hot jalapeno jarred slices.

5. Serve with Ritz crackers. I haven't tried french bread as one reviewer stated, but Ritz crackers were much much better than chips.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-11-26T01:08:26.61

carrief

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved it at the BBQ. Didn't adjust the ingredients as listed on the recipe except for adding about 2 additional ounces of jalapenos. When I tasted it before I baked it, I thought it needed a little more flavor and I was out of green chilies or I would have added those instead. After baking, as other reviewers warned the parm cheese will turn into kind of a thick glob on top of the dish which as it cools becomes harder to "dip" through with a chip or baguette. Thus I put a spoon in the dish to help people scoop through the cheese layer. No one seemed to mind. Next time will mix in 1/2 c. panko bread crumbs with the parm cheese as others have suggested to help the cheese be easier to dip through. This is a keeper!
Review:

city:

country:
None
text:
it was definitely easy.  I followed the recipe exactly but found it came up short comparing it to a jalapeno popper flavor.  after tasting it beforehand, I went ahead and added the other 2 oz from the can but it didn't do much to add any jalapeno flavor. I think what is missing is the fresh taste of jalapeno.  this may be better using fresh jalapenos instead(as one would find with eating an actual popper) and roasting them beforehand then chopping them up to add, instead of using canned.  I also didn't care for the parmesan on top and found it a tad strange that this was the cheese of choice, seeing how most poppers use cheddar or a cheddar jack. the two flavors didn't mesh well for me.  I used fresh parm too.  maybe adding the cheese to the mixture then crushing some ritz crackers, or some dried breadcrumbs on top might make it seem more true to the name.

text:
This recipe is a hit!  I used low-fat cream cheese, reduced the mayo (lo-fat)by half, and replaced the other half with lo-fat sour cream.  Following other reviewers suggestions, I omitted the green chilies and used fresh jalapeno peppers.  I also mixed panko bread crumbs with the Parmesan cheese, sprinkled it on top, and baked in a 375 degree oven about 1/2 hour.  I was serving this for 3 people, so made half a recipe, planning on left-overs, but it was gone in no time.
Thank you for a simple, delicious recipe!

text:
I made this dip recently with a couple of changes:  (1) Canned jalapenos are no substitution for fresh.   Take the time to use fresh and it will make the difference.  I used six as was recommended by another reviewer. 

(2)  Poppers in restaurants near me often include ground sausage.  I added 1 lb. of browned Bob Evans Zesty Pork Sausage which was a nice addition to the dip.  

(3) I agree with the other reviewers and used 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream.  I also used panko bread crumbs on top for a nice crunch.

Display Name:
dishin'itupinOH

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good dip, and would appeal to anyone who enjoys jalapeno poppers, however I did make some changes as stated below.  

I made this twice; the first time, exactly as indicated in the recipe, except I added a panko and parmesean mix to the top before baking.  Because everyone's heat tolerance is different, and it is so subjective, I will try to give you an idea of the heat in this dip, as I made it a few different ways.  I would rate the "heat index" as follows:  if you can barely take any heat at all, then make it with the 2 oz. of diced, canned jalapenos.  After I tried it when it came out of the oven, and realized that the heat was barely noticeable--mostly a mayo and chile taste.  I decided to just mix in another oz. of the diced canned jalapenos.  This made a small difference, but not much.  

The second time I made the dip, I used the whole 4 oz. can, and it definitely bumped up the heat index, more to a level of a mild popper, while still appealing to most taste buds, in my opinion.

I am not a huge heat lover, but I will say that over the last few years, my tolerance is increasing. The second time I made this, it was fine for my taste buds.  Just enough.

text:
OMG--delicious.  I used fresh jalapenos--2 without seeds/ribs and 2 with.  Just the right amount of heat.  I mixed in half the parmesan and sprinkled half on top, but next time I think I'll mix all of it in, as the top got a little too hard when it started to cool.  I used red and yellow bell peppers as dippers and could have eaten every bit of it all by myself!!!

Update 9/18/2015:   This dip is fantastic.  I've made it many times and it is now requested by everyone at work whenever we have any kind of party.  I usually use 1/2 cup mayo and 1/2 cup sour cream, but I made it last weekend for a shower and afterward realized that I had forgotten the mayo.  Not to worry--it was even better without it, not quite as greasy.  I do mix all the parmesan into the spread, as putting it on top made it harder to eat, in my opinion.  And I highly recommend using fresh jalapenos.  I can't tell you how many people have asked for this recipe.  It's really delicious!!

As with everything, I added extras to this recipie. I added a bit of brown sugar to sweeten it. I also added a couple fresh Jalapenos that had been chopped. I put it in at 350 and let it go about 30 minutes.

text:
Another "keeper"! Served this at this years Annual Super Bowl Party (75 people) and not a smidgen was left. It was extremely easy to assemble, which I did the day before, and 30 minutes before the party started, we popped this in my trusty Breville Smart Oven and Viola! Yummy goodness! The only thing I changed, based on another reviewer's suggestion, was to mix 1/2 cup of Panko crumbs with the freshly grated Parmesan cheese for the topping. It really came out to perfection. Being a Texan, many of my friends like a little spice, so I chose this for the "hot and spicy" offering to go along with Guacamole, BLT Dip and Red Pepper Bean Dip. Everything was enjoyed, but this was the only dip that was completely finished. Had planned on serving with toasted french bread but the server burned it (Oops!), so we used Pita Chips. Thanks for a great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is excellent, although it really should be called a dip rather than a spread and more people might find the recipe this way.  Made it last year for the Super Bowl and nobody really ate it, but I was pleasantly surprised and took what I couldn't eat into work the next day and they devoured it!  Now I make it regularly for work birthdays and everyone loves it, even people who can't handle a lot of heat.  I sprinkle the cheese on top and bake for 350 for ~20 minutes until the cheese is melted and browned a little...I have never tried microwaving it. Great with butter crackers, but tortilla chips are also good.  Plus, if you love lots of "pop" you could add more jalapenos to your liking.

text:
OMG, This was wonderful and loved by all! I doubled the amount of jalapenos and i was perfect. Since I already had a large jar of them, I simply diced them myself and used the green chilies can to measure equal amounts of both. This was sooooo yummy with sliced baguettes. So easy, fast, and delish! I read the ingredients quickly before shopping and had to use the "green can" style parm, too, but it was still very good. I didn't measure it, but just generously covered the top - probably less than what the fresh parm called for. Thank you! We will be having this again very soon! Almost forgot - I always use Publix brand neufchatel instead of cream cheese as this brand tastes identical and is less fattening. Do NOT use other brand neufchatel cheese, Publix brand is the only one that tastes just like cream cheese.

text:
I mix it up a bit. Cook 3 slices of bacon on stove, Cut bacon real fine. Add bacon grease and chunks to dip. Instead of 1 cup mayo, I do 2/3 cup mayo, 1/3 cup sour cream. I add 1/2 cup of shredded cheddar cheese to dip as well. For the top, I layer it with about 1/4 cup cheddar, 1/4 cup bread crumbs, and 1/4 cup Parmesan! So delish!

I am speechless.  I took one look at the teeny-tiny list of ingredients and thought, "It must need SOMETHING"!  Wrong!!!  One of my co-workers mentioned at the end of the day on Thursday that we should have a "dip day" on Friday to celebrate the coming weekend.  I saw this recipe and since I had most of the ingredients, I thought - why not.  So glad I did.  I completely agree that with others that it should be heated in the oven.  The only time I strayed from the original recipe was when I added Tex-Mex shredded cheese on top of the dip and then mixed the parmesan with breadcrumbs (as others have suggested).  My dip was the hit of "dip day"!!!  Will use this at every gathering from now on!!!

country:
None
text:
This was delicious!!  I used most of a 4 oz can of jalapenos and chopped up and added 4 fresh ones (seeded) as well.  We like things spicy!  I also used a thin layer of cheddar jack cheese on top of the spread ingredients and then put the parmesan cheese with bread crumbs over that.  I sprayed the top with Crisco cooking spray.  It created a wonderful "popper-y" kind of breading.  I baked for about 40 minutes at 300 degrees.  Everyone really loved it, especially my husband!  We love jalapeno poppers, but they aren't easy to make at all and this was just as good.  We used buttercrisp crackers for serving, but I think next time we will use plain bagel chips.  Really great spread/dip, perfect for gatherings and football games!

text:
Awesome recipe!!!  Great for football parties, potluck, and any occasion that you want a super tasty and easy appetizer.  I used all 4 ounces of the canned, diced jalapeno peppers and I thought it gave it the perfect amound of heat.  It had a little kick without burning your mouth.  I mixed the cream cheese with the mayonnaise, then added the peppers and parmesan cheese.  I stirred it until everything was well blended and then put it all in my little 2-quart crockpot.  I cooked it on low for 3 hours and then turned it down to warm.  I took it to work and it was gone before lunch was over.  I served it with Triscuits and tortilla chips.  Everyone went crazy over this dish, and I had many, many requests for the recipe.  I'm making this again this weekend for my granddaughter's birthday party.  Thanks for sharing such a wonderful dish!  :)

text:
If I could rate this 10 stars, I would... The baked version, with breadcrumbs (panko is great, but regular/italian/seasoned works just fine) mixed into the parmesean is AMAZING and totally addictive. I add about 1/2-3/4 c shredded mexican blend cheese, and the whole 4oz can of jalapenos, also I use a 7oz can of green chiles.. Bake at 350 or 375 for abt 30 until brown, and OMG! The microwaved version works pretty well though, esp if you dont have the option of baking.. Definitely a new go-to potluck/party standby!

SUPER RECIPE!  I've brought it to many parties, and there is never any left over and I am always asked for the recipe by several people at each party.    I actually DOUBLE the diced drained jalapenos to give it a real kick, and everyone loves it that way - but I am in southern Texas, so take that into consideration!  If that sounds like too much jalapeno for you, try increasing the jalapenos just a little at a time.

Simple and delicious!  I do the baked version, and double the jalapenos. (I use the kind in a jar.)  I suggest using 1/2 mayo and 1/2 sour cream.  The first time I made it, the flavor of the mayo was way too much, almost overwhelming the dish.  I also mix Panko in with the parmesan, 3:1 ratio.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this for my fiance's birthday party.  He loves cheese and he absolutely adores anything spicy so I thought it would be the perfect dish to serve as an appetizer.  It definitely was!  Everyone ate it up and loved it!  Next time I will have to make a double batch because it went quick and everyone wanted more.  I did change a few things, I added some shredded cheddar cheese into the mixture and sprinkles fresh parmesan cheese and panko breadcrumbs on top.  I used the baked variation because I really wanted a crunchy top-just like a baked jalapeno popper!  It turned out great- the spice factor is just right, I think if you added any more it would take away from the taste of the dish.  Very easy to put together, and cheap to make-I think the most expensive part was the parmesan cheese! I served with regular & jalapeno flavored tortilla chips.  Definitely a hit!

text:

I thought the dip tasted awful before I baked it and was sure that the mayonnaise ruined it. But after it baked it was GREAT! Everyone was totally impressed and my boyfriend said he heard someone saying what a great cook I was :)

text:
i tried very hard to follow this recipe completely, but was unable to. Sadly my local grocery store doesn't have canned chili peppers. Grrr. I used a little more of the jalapenos (jarred not canned.. same reason) and cut up a fresh pepper of an unknown name. i know it to be extra spicy so i took out most of the seeds.   because of the changes i couldn't help (and the fact that i took out most of the seeds of the one item that was hot), the dip was way to mild. i ended up adding a shake of a chili sauce. little shake, not much.   despite all the changes i couldn't prevent.. the dip was very well liked. it had the yumminess of the jalapeno peppers without being overpowering for those who don't like spice.   sadly, I didn't get to take any home. next time i will make some to keep at home too!

text:
This dip is seriously addicting. I've made it as the recipe is written and it is really good, but using suggestions of other reviewers it is even better.  I mix the parmesan cheese into with the rest of the ingredients and add a layer of panko crumbs to the top. Bake for about 45 minutes at 350 and it comes out PERFECT. Make sure you get grated parmesan if you can - it's SO much better. Depending on who is eating it I adjust the amount of jalapeno as well. OMNOMNOM

I stuck to the recipe but just added 1/2 panko and 1/2 parmesan cheese mixture to the top and baked it in the oven.  (I like it spicy so I also added some fresh jalapenos.)  One alternate serving suggestion that people seemed to like:  
I baked cornbread (thin layer) and spread jalapeno jelly on the cornbread, topped with the dip (and panko bread crumbs and parmesan cheese on top) and then broiled it.

country:

text:
The first time I made this I accidentally doubled the jalapenos. I also used plain bread crumbs with fresh grated Parmesan cheese. I baked it for about 20-25 minutes in the oven at 400. I thought it was yummy like that! I just made it again and used Panko crumbs with fresh grated Parmesan cheese, still doubling the jalapenos and baking in the oven at 400 degrees. YUMMY! It was even BETTER!!! It is a spicy, so if you don't like spicy leave the jalapenos at 2 oz. (I happen to like clearing out my sinuses every now and then!) The Panko crumbs really do make all the difference making the topping all crusty. I highly recommend those over regular bread crumbs.

3710312
Display Name:
StaceyMB
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
RAVE REWIEWS ON BAKED VERSION!! After returning from a long weekend of camping, I needed something fast and simple to make for a house warming party.  This was fast, simple, and most of all absolutely delicious!  I made it again the very next Sunday for a family birthday party.  It was the talk of the party.  I did alter the recipe a bit.  First of all, I couldn't find chopped green chilies, so I used 1/4th cup diced hot yellow peppers and 1/4th cup diced jalapeno peppers (these peppers are HOT, so the cut back IS necessary, but will still make a spicy dip). Also, I used 1/2 of an 8oz parmesan cheese package and also added shredded cheddar.  I placed the mixture into a aluminum throwaway baking dish, and then lightly coated the top of the mixture with breadcrumbs that were tossed with the remaining parmesan.  Lastly, I placed sliced jalapenos on top to decorate.  MUST BAKE!! Bake at about 400 for 20-30 minutes.  I baked it about half way at home, and finished baking at the party.  The breadcrumbs and parmesan will turn to a nice golden brown. Well worth the wait.

text:
Just made this for a bridal shower. EVERYONE wanted the recipe - they were eating it on toasted baguette slices... tortilla chips... with a spoon... you name it. It is AWESOME. Made the recipes as is, except I had half a fresh jalapeno, so I chopped added it (no seeds) with the canned...and I mixed 1/2 cup of parmesan into the cream cheese mixture and topped the whole thing with the other 1/2 cup, so the cheese on top wouldn't be so thick (I used a smaller rectangle dish to bake). AND, I baked it in the oven for about 20 minutes until bubbly. OMG. It was just delicious. (I used low fat mayo... you'd never know).

BEST HOT DIP EVER!! Everyone loves this one.  It's great cause you can adjust the amount of heat with the amount of jalapenos you use. text:
This recipe is AWESOME!!  Made it for my fiance since he LOVES jalapenos and all things hot...but the rest of us enjoy it too.  I am not too much of a fan of spicy food at all.... I bought the regular Great Value brand of sliced jalapenos in the 12 oz jar, and used about 1/3 of the jar, and it has a bite to it, but not so much that I can't enjoy it too.  The idea about using the Panko bread crumbs mixed with the parmesean and baking in a 400 degree oven for 20 minutes is a fantastic idea....gives it the exact popper taste.  Thanks so much for sharing... I will be making this again and again I'm sure.

This came out awesome however I made a couple of alterterations to save some caleries and fat. userID:
3249485
Display Name:
DanaCH
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
256
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome!  after reading the reviews and then the reply by the original author, I decided to keep the original recipe exactly as-is except for one thing - i put 1/2 cup fresh grated parmigiano in the mix and the other 1/2 cup added to 1/2 cup of breadcrumbs and then spread on the top.  i warmed the dip up in the microwave and then put it in my toaster oven to lightly toast the topping.  I'm glad i didn't heat it the whole time in the oven or the topping would have become too toasted or even burned.  Also, i would recommend using a shallow dish to heat/serve if you use this amount of breadcrumb mix so the proportion of dip to topping is better.    I was skeptical about using the parmigiano, like one of the reviewers said - cheddar or jack seem more appropriate but the flavor mix was really great.  I also took the author's recommendation to double the jalapenos if you want a little more heat.  It ended up comfortably warm, no one thought it was too much.  (by the way, i used 'pickled' jalapeno slices that i chopped up - nice tangy heat)

Made this according to directions and do not like the overpowering mayo flavor in it.....I believe it would be better substituting sour cream and using the seasoned bread crumbs on top with the cheese.  I used real cheese and baked it in the oven. Mayo was miracle whip as regular mayo is too strong in dips for my liking. Even my kids who are NOT picky eaters didn't like it. For extra kick, I did layer some sliced jalapenos on top and that turned out well. It's the flavor of the base we don't like.

Display Name:
Todd

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/327352.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great appetizer.  I don't use the canned chilies or jalapenos.  I've found that using 6-10 fresh jalapenos works great for taste and heat.  If you like it hot just cut up the jalapeno. Or if you don't want things too kicked up, clean out the seeds and white membrane to get the level of heat you'd like.  To get more jalapeno taste, I cut cut each jalapeno ring in half so there's more coverage in the dip.  I also bake in the oven for 30 min at 375 and then stir the parmesan throughout the dip after I take it out of the oven.

text:
This is very yummy and DOES taste a lot like poppers. We made a half batch and it still made quite a bit. It is very rich so unless you have a lot of people to help you eat it you might want to make a half batch. I made it in the oven...about 15-20 minutes at 350 and the parmesean cheese on top was nice and melty. I tried one side with just the cheese and the other side with cheese and bread crumbs (like others had recommended). I didn't really like the bread crumb side as well, so next time I would leave them off. It tasted great on chips, would also be yummy on Triscuits or bread, I think.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OH MY GOSH! This has to be the most amazing dip I've ever had. I made it for a party for a friend. I did put a lot more jalepenos in it than it calls for, probably double or triple. I just kept chopping them until I thought I had enough. I put the parmesan and breadcrumbs on top, and then baked a small amount to taste it. Baking it brings out the jalepeno flavor. That was good.... BUT, since I was making a lot of snacks for this party, I decided to make this ahead. I mixed it up and put it in the fridge and baked it the next day. Being in the fridge overnight REALLY brought out the jalepeno flavor. In the future, I will ALWAYS make it this way since it was SO much better the next day. There were only about half a dozen people at the party, but this dip was gone in about an hour. Its just about the best thing ever.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-12-30T17:54:54.6
helpfulCount:
0

701710

I have made this three times over the holiday season...everyone loves it. I took it to work for a Christmas party and it was eaten up! I was even asked for the recipe by a couple of co-workers. Instead of microwaving, I did pop it in the oven at 350 degrees until the parmesan cheese melted. There is also a similar recipe on the site that recommends mixing the parm with the other ingredients and putting in a bread bowl. i think I will  try that method next as the parm makes the taste for me. Thanks for sharing...i loved the Kraft spreads and this was better!

text:
Used baked option for my first attempt at this.  Was told "that is the best thing I have ever tasted" and "Yum, yum"... throughout the night.  Be warned, something about this just keeps bringing you back for more.  I felt like a stuffed jalape√±o about to "pop" myself when the evening was done because I found myself back nibbling on the dip all night long.  Simply done, simply superb, simply delicious.    I followed directions but did use 4 oz jalape√±o and added 4 that were seeded and sliced on top for decorations.  I cooked the dip in a glass pie pan, after 20 minutes placed sliced jalape√±os on top, and cooked another 10.  Nice presentation.    Seeded and sliced jalape√±os were not too hot, nor was the rest of the spread.  Most anything placed into this "spread" or "dip" was very good.    Many people like to "tweak" recipes and I am one, so I may try the bread crumbs variation next time, but why mess with something that is so good just as it is.   This will certainly be a keeper and will be presented to family and friends as long as I have a kitchen to cook in and an event to prepare for.   Thanks for the fantastic recipe.

country:
None
text:
Liked this one a lot. Changed with other's suggestions: used 5 fresh jalapenos, finely diced; half mayo/half sour cream; added 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese; added 1/4 cup cilantro. Topped with 1/2 cup panko and parmesan mixed.  I'll reduce the panko to 1/4 cup next time - seemed too crumbly to my liking.  Coooked in oven instead of microwave. Served with broiled baguette slices.  My husband thought bacon would be good, but others mentioned it wasn't.  I'm thinking maybe crumbling cooked bacon over the top after it's done, instead of in the dish itself, would be an idea.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A huge hit, two weeks in a row!  I used 1 regular  and 1 lowfat cm. cheese as well as 1/2c regular and 1/2 c light mayo.  Add as many jalepenos as you want, I just kept tasting as I added them. Whip cream cheese first for smoother consistency with a beater or imersion blender.  Added in about 1/2 cup  parmesean cheese from the can into dip, then put the shredded on top.  Bake 350 for 1/2 hour, spread on toasted bread, triscuits, or wheat ritz.  Men couldn't step away from the food counter!!  Now a new regular in my "mix" of appetizers.

text:
When I saw this recipe I couldn't wait to try it. I have a candleshow coming up in a couple of weeks and have been looking at different recipes but I like to try them out before making it for anyone. Wow! This is a good one. I didn't have the green chilies on hand and did not have the amount of cream cheese to make the large serving.  I used 1/2 cup jared jalepenos instead and used 1/4 cup sour cream and 2 Tbs. Mayo and 4 oz. cream cheese. I also mixed in 1/2 cup shredded cheddar then topped with the breadcrumb and italian cheese mix. This made enough for 2 I used a little soufle dish and baked for 1/2 hour. I crisped up some flatbread to make like crackers, was excellant. I will use this for my party and any event I have coming up. Thanks for sharing a wonderful recipe Denise.

text:
EXCELLENT!! I had a big crowd so increased as I thought fit and the results were perfect.. used 3 blocks of cream cheese, a 4 oz can of chopped jalapenos, a 7 oz can of chopped grn chilies and stuck w/ 1 c of mayo. I put all of this in an 8x8 dish topped w/ parmsean and bread crumbs (I really wanted to use panko but I was out, I will next time) sprayed with olive oil and baked at 325 for 25 min. everyone went nuts over this and I even had men emailing me for the recipe the following day. I could have easily doubled what I did and it would have been gone! The kids loved it as well. I served with Triscuit Thin Crisp and Pita Chips...This was a winner!

text:
Excellent!  I took advice of others and used 1/2 mayo. 1/2 sourcream. I put around 1/4 cup of Parmesan in the mix.  I couldn't find diced jalapenos so ended up dicing one fresh one.  It added plenty of taste and heat.  I didn't want it too hot since children would be trying it.  It was excellent.  I topped with with the panko and parmesan and baked it.  Served with toasted (olive oil, salt and pepper)bagette slices.  Fantastic!  I have received requests for recipes, so you know it is good!  Thanks Denise!

text:
I took this to a 4th of July picnic.  OMG! everyone went crazy for it!  I followed some of the other reviewers suggestions- omitting the green chilies, adding 4 fresh jalapenos finely diced to the jarred, used 1/2 cup mayo and 1/2 cup sour cream, substituted shredded Mexican blend cheese for the Parmesan.  I topped the dip with 1/2 cup of breadcrumbs that I mixed with melted butter.  I served the dip with thinly sliced baguette slices (that I drizzled with olive oil, dash of garlic salt, and toasted in the broiler) and Triscuit Thin Crisps.  The Triscuits were the preferred dipper!!  Everyone said that it tasted just like a jalapeno popper!  One friend said he'd eat this off a bumper!  So delicious!  Thank you Denise, for the great recipe!!

text:
I know it's not fair to rate a recipe once you've modified it, but the reality is I love to cook and I can never follow a recipe as is. I read so many responses and took from them what I thought would turn out to be yummy. I did like so many, 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 mayo, that combo never fails. I also added about 4 oz. of sharp cheddar cheese into the mixture, an absolute MUST. I did the parmesan cheese/panko topping. It was really fine without it. I think my parmesan was too authentic, it didn't melt well quickly, so it sort of came up as a whole piece when on low broil. I pulled it off and the dip alone was fine. I'd probably skip out on the parmesan topping next time. And yes, use a toasted italian bread or pita crisps. A definate re-maker.

I have made this recipe over 20 times. Every party I go to, people request that I bring this dip. text:
I followed the suggestions (amendments) and used the Panko vrumbs. I ended up having to turn the oven to lo broil once it was simmering, to brown the bread crumbs. Next time I am just going to microwave it, because if someone can't enjoy the flavor without it looking pretty, that is on them. I quadrupled the recipe because I was going to a party with over 100 guests. I toasted the french bread slices, but many people just used the Tortilla chips as well. I think the Fritoe Scoops might make it too salty. By far, the easiest and tastiest app I have ever brought to a party.

text:
i made this dip simply because of the amazing reviews. i was questioning how good it would actually be because the ingredients were some simple. boy was i surprised. this is one of the most delicious party foods i have ever made. there was a ton of food there too, but my dish was cleaned out. everyone was asking me for the recipe.   i also changed the recipe as suggested by others. used 1/2 mayo 1/2 sour creme, added bank bread crumbs on top, baked in the oven, and added about 3 ounces of jalapenos. it didn't have enough heat with just 2.   served with fritos, but people were also eating it with tortilla chips from someone's other dip.   *** the parmesan cheese hardened on top after i baked it in the oven and let it cool. made it kind of difficult to break through the crust to get to the warm dip part***

text:
Wow, I was worried because even if recipes get great ratings I always seem to do something wrong.  I followed recipe very closely except added 4 0z. japs and about 1/3 diced serrano, I only had 3/4 cup of mayo left so I substituted the remaining sourcream. Mixed parm with dip, microwaved (cuz was running late) for 3 minutes, sprinkled more parm on top and broiled for about 6 minutes.  Rave reviews, not a drop left.  Men and Women both loved.  It def had some kick to it from the serrano. Yum thanks for the great recipe, it's a keeper!

text:
I hate to review this recipe lower than a five, but I thought the cream cheese was a little over powering. Otherwise, the taste was pretty good. I did what other reviewers suggested and added bread crumbs to the top before baking for 25 minutes at 400 degrees. I think 1/2 cup is too much, if I make it again I'll use more like 1/4 or maybe even less (mixed in with the fresh grated parmesan). At the party I took it to, half RAVED about it and the other half didn't really have much to say. It makes a lot more than other spreads/dips I've tried, so next time I might scale it back to half!

A delicious appetizer. Of course, I did change the recipe a bit. Other reviewers suggested cheddar cheese..so I used both parmesan cheese and about 1/4-1/2 C shredded cheddar cheese and because I had them handy I drained a small can of artichoke hearts chopped them and added to the dip. text:

I divide it into two seperate baking crocks and bake.  We love it with tortillia chips.  When having a party I make 3-4 batches for 6-8 crocks to set out.

text:
I made this recipe with miracle whip instead of mayo.  Do not make the same mistake as I did.  I think this recipe probably tastes really good if made exactly to the recipe, however it is terribly fatty.  I read the reviews not to make any substitution... so I went to the store and bought mayo.  Long story short when I was reading the label and seeing the 100 calories per tablespoon I freaked and subbed the miracle whip last minute.  I will definately try to make this recipe again. It just sounds so good! Exactly like something all my friends would like... but I might try the half mayo and half sour cream option some reviewers have said.  I simply cannot justify making this full fat.

text:
WOW! We love jalapeno poppers and this was great!!! I would give it 10 stars if I could.
This is what I did- I used the suggested cream cheese (I used Lite) and the Mayo, I added maybe 1/2-3/4 cup of Shredded Cheddar, and 1/4 cup of parm. Stirred that up and put some more cheddar on top.  
I used the suggested chiles and used FRESH jalapeno's (7 of them). 
I baked at 300 for 20 minutes....and wow...TO DIE FOR! :) This will be a staple for parties for years to come!:)
THANK YOU!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't believe how insane my family and friends went for this dip. I followed the advice of other reviewers and used 4 oz. of jalapenos to get a decent level of heat. I also combined the cup of parmesan with a 1/2 cup of panko and mixed it with a few splashes of oil before spreading it on top of the dip. Mixing the cheese and panko together (instead of layering) prevents them from forming a tough crust that is hard for the bread or chip to get through. I am asked to bring this at every family function...they love it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic and so simple. I lightened it by using low fat cream cheese and canola mayo, but it was still VERY rich. Also the topping others have mentioned adds so much -- I microwaved the dip until warm and then put it in a shallow oven-safe dish and topped with a mix of parm, panko bread crumbs (Ian's brand is great) and a sprinkle olive oil, then baked at 400 until topping was browned and bubbly. Served with french bread slices; agree with others that chips like fritos overpower the dip.  Microwaving first and then browning in toaster oven saves time on this recipe.  Thanks for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This recipe is FANTASTIC!!  I substituted 8oz of the cream cheese with the ‚Äú1/3 reduced fat cream cheese‚Äù and it still turned out great.  I did add a 1/4 cup of bread crumbs to the top of the dish before I put it in the oven and it turned the top into a beautiful golden brown color and was easy to break through with the baguettes.  I toasted 1/4" thick slices of a baguette in the oven and served hot with the dip.  It was a great success at our dinner.  

One note, next time I make this recipe, I will definitely mix in about 1/4 cup of freshly grated parmesan cheese to the mixture.

I will make this again and again!

text:
This was really good even with the modifications I made. I made this with what I had on hand so I reduced serving size down to 8. I used reduced fat cream cheese,shredded parmesan and a little panko crumbs on top. I sprayed the top lightly with Pam cooking spray to crisp up. I put it in the oven at 375 for about 25 min. I served it with tortilla chips and also Ritz crackers. The Ritz were better because it gave it the crispy texture. This was so good that my husband and I finished the whole thing. Yum.

I made this recipe exactly as written (so often the reviews say they liked this dip, but they changed everything about it, making it not this dip at all!) and it was great!  I made it twice and the second time I put in a little less mayo and I liked it even more.  I use Canola oil mayo and I think the flavor of that mayo is a little different then your usual mayonnaise.  I also just used regular kraft Parmesan cheese cause that's what I had, and it was very tasty.  I served it with white corn chips and it was sooooo good!  Thanks for the great recipe:-)

text:
This was just okay. I was actually surprised it has had such great ratings. I took others advice (added more chilis, panko breadcrumbs w/butter on top.. put in oven, not micro..) and it came out ok but then as it cooled it hard and tough to eat. Maybe micro is the way to go. Will not make again though, and I LOVE spicy foods, but this lacked something. I'll stick with the Buffalo Chicken Dip which we like a lot. But if you try this, I wouldn't put it in the oven, or bother with the breadcrumbs, it only dries out this dip. Good luck!

text:
OUTSTANDING! I have been wanting to try this recipe for so long and I am glad I did! So simple and easy it's almost too good to be true. You would think it needs something else, but it sure doesn't! I followed the recipe but added about 3/4 cup of crushed croutons to the top to add a crunch, and baked for about 20 min. instead of microwaving. I would highly recommend adding a bread crumb topping and baking to complete this amazing dip. I used tortilla chips and baked french bread chunks, can't decide which one was better liked, it was great both ways. This is my new go-to dip, and the most important recommendation would probably be to double the recipe, because it sure doesn't stick around for long!

I tried this last night and enjoyed it.  I cut the recipe in half, and used "hot" vs "mild" green chilis and jalapenos. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really phenomenal dip!  The reason I give it 4 instead of 5 stars is that I had to add waaaay more jalepenos than called for in the original recipe.  I like things moderately spicy so I started out with the recommended amount of peppers but I couldn't even taste them! I kept adding and tasting and by the time I was done I had used 4 ounces of chiles and 12 ounces of jalepenos!  Not one person at the party I brought this to thought it was too hot.  Do not try this dip cold,  all you will taste is mayonaise, but once heated (I baked mine) you just get the lovely cream cheese and parmesan flavor.  The consistency was really nice too,  not too runny but not too thick.  Everyone LOVED it!

Outstanding! One thing we do add is about 1/3 cup of finely-minced PECANS. Pound pecans in a ziploc bag and blend them in w/the mixture--lots of flavor without a "nutty" taste. Balances the kick of the recipe. Easily adjusted--hotter or milder as you like it. Excellent! Thanks so much!

text:
This was a good recipe but I made a few changes.  I used 6 fresh jalapenos that i chopped very fine, seeds and all.  I didn't use the canned chilis.  I microwaved the ingredients for about a minute to soften them and then mixed.  Spread into a pie pan and sprinkled a mixture of breadcrumbs and fresh parm cheese and baked in the oven until bubbly. Served with triscuits. Next time I will have to make a double batch because the dip was gone before all of the guests even arrived!!

also, i used reduced fat cc and mayo! :)

I have never had something go over as big as this did last night.  I took this to a camping potluck and it was all everyone was asking; who brought it and what's in it? SO simple. text:
The best! These are the changes I incorporated based on previous reviewers suggestions: 1/2 c sour cream and 1/2 c mayo, 4 oz jalapenos, 1/2 c grated parm mixed into the dip. For the topping I mixed 1/2 c grated parm with 1/2 c panko, spread it on top and baked for 25-30 minutes at 375, until hot and bubbly. I took it to a party last night and people loved it.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great dip!  I started out cutting down to a half recipe... one package of cream cheese, one half cup of mayo, and one half cup of grated Parmesan, since there were only going to be three people eating it.  I made it using two ounces of green chiles and one ounce of Jalape√±os, then tasted it.  I have a pretty high tolerance for spicy, so I ended up using the whole 4 ounce can of jalape√±os, and I liked the flavor of the green chiles, so I used the whole 4 ounce can of that as well.  Nuked it for a couple of minutes then put it into a small slow cooker.  It was truly addictive!!!  Actually only two of us were really eating it, and we just about polished off the entire batch!  Although all agreed that it was better when it was stirred together so the Parmesan wasn't a layer on top but rather mixed into the dip.  But that's just personal preference.  Also, I think I'll take it up another notch or two the next time and use even MORE Jalape√±os!!!  Thanks for a great recipe, I'll definitely make this one again.

DELICIOUS!!! I have been making this for years. I used "Tamed" jalapenos, and it gives it just enough spiciness without being overpowering. text:
I wanted to serve this as a cold dip because it's too hot up here to turn on the oven.  But because I didn't bake it, I think that prevented the jalapeno flavor from getting into all that cream cheese.  I also used sour cream in place of the mayo.  To make it give it more flavor I added 1/4 c. jalapeno juice from the jar and twice as much jalapeno and left out the cheese.  Before I made the adjustments no one was interested, but after I mixed it up the spread/dip was thinner & easier to eat with corn chips and people seemed to eat a lot more of it.

For the top I crushed up wheat Ritz crackers with the parm cheese and added a little asiago cheese too.  Took it to a gathering and it disappeared!  ruffles go well with it since they have alot of salt.  thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe was very very good!  I made enough to serve 16.

I added a pinch of garlic powder, 2 tablespoons finely chopped sweet onion and doubled the jalapeno peppers.  I used about a 1/4 cup very finely grated monterey jack cheese, topped with breadcrumbs and baked it.  It browned beautifully and tasted wonderful served with warmed tortilla chips.

My only complaint is it didn't last long enough....I'll have to make a bigger batch next time :-)

I haven't grown sick of it yet!

text:
this dip is awesome. i have made it about 4 times since the first try, for a variety of crowds, and everyone loves it. make sure not to put more mayo than the recipe calls for (i try to use a bit less). if you overdo it, the dip gets jiggly and the mayo washes out some of the flavor. i've only served it with tortilla chips. i'm interested to try it with bread, but have no complaints on using chips. still super delicious!

This was DELICIOUS and a total hit w/ my friends! This was rockin'!  I subbed yogurt for mayo because I can't stomach the stuff.  I also couldn't find canned/jarred chilies at the store (they used to have them, wth?!), so I just left them out. I used hot jarred jalapenos and to me it was spicy.  However, I don't normally eat jalapenos so I'm sure my taste for them isn't developed!  I served with some bread cubes I had made and bf's only complaint was that I cubed the bread too small.  We have leftovers, but I'm sure he'll eat them since he ate a good bit on his own with dinner tonight.

text:
This is one of the best dips I have ever made! I was recently informed by a friend that this was to be "my thing" for bringing to any parties at his place. The first time I made it I did not find it very spicy, but I have since learned that the key to optimal flavor and spice is to make it at least a day in advance a let it sit. It definitely gets hotter with time. I have also made this with sour cream in place of the mayo (because I ran out) and it didn't affect the flavor much.

text:
I'm always asked to bring this dip to parties. I pretty much follow the recipe, but now mix the cup of freshly grated Parmesan into the cream cheese mixture, reserving a small amount for the top that I mix with some Italian bread crumbs. I always bake it till edges are just starting to brown.  Add in more green chilies and mild pickled jalapenos for more flavor. The dip still remains delicious once cooled.

text:
Great idea - thanks for sharing! I followed the general idea of this recipe, but changed parts of it to suit what ingredients I had on hand. I made a smaller batch using about 6oz reduced fat plain cream cheese, 2oz spinach cream cheese, 1/4c white american cheese (cubed), 1/4c mayo, and two fresh jalape√±os (cleaned and diced.) I put the mixture in an oven-safe baking dish, topped it with grated Parmesan and a thin layer of breadcrumbs and baked it until hot and bubbly. Still tasted good, like jalape√±o poppers, but it could have used more jalape√±o. Next time I will try it using the canned chilies and maybe some cheddar cheese.

text:
Let me start out by saying I LOVE jalape√±o poppers!!  I did like this spread.  I only used about 3/4 of 1 can of jalape√±os and thought that was the right temp for us, spicy but not 'knock your socks off I can't eat another bite without some water' spicy.  I do recommend to mix in some cheddar cheese with the spread instead of on top for a more realistic jalape√±o popper taste.  I also sprinkled some bread crumbs on top and sprayed with butter.  I ABSOLUTELY recommend warming up this dish in the oven!  Also, I think next time I make this I will add 2 cans of chili's and only 1 can of jalape√±os.  We served with scoop tortilla chips and that was good, but I'm sure there is a better "dipper" for this recipe....Thanks!!

text:
This dip was delicious and got rave reviews by everyone at the party where I served it.  I tend to like things spicy, so I used close to 4 oz. of the canned jalepenos, rather than the 2 oz. that this recipe called for.  I mixed the ingredients with a hand mixer, which was easy and made it fluffy.  I used about half the amount of parmesan that was called for, and I sprinkled the top with some chopped fresh jalepenos.  I baked in the oven until it was hot through, and then turned on the broiler for just a minute or two to brown the top.  It was wonderful!  Will definitely make again.
